row.Content:
The Manufacturing edition of Acumatica ERP delivers powerful and comprehensive functionality for make-to-stock, make-to-order, engineer-to-order, project-centric, job shop, batch, and repetitive manufacturing companies. It is an easy-to-use and powerful solution designed to be used by a wide range of organizations with simple to advanced business flow and reporting needs.{br}
In this guide, you will find information about implementation and usage of Manufacturing edition.
row.PlainText: Manufacturing The Manufacturing edition of Acumatica ERP delivers powerful and comprehensive functionality for make-to-stock, make-to-order, engineer-to-order, project-centric, job shop, batch, and repetitive manufacturing companies. It is an easy-to-use and powerful solution designed to be used by a wide range of organizations with simple to advanced business flow and reporting needs. In this guide, you will find information about implementation and usage of Manufacturing edition.

row.column: Implementing Manufacturing These are the steps required to configure and implement the Advanced Management Edition modules. The manufacturing modules are integrated with the distribution, finances, and CRM modules. For example: Sales Orders create demand for and consume production. Purchase Orders provide supply to production. Inventory items are used to define the bills of materials for the products produced. Production orders consume and produce inventory. Inventory items are used in estimates and the product configurator. Estimates and product configurations can be used in CRM opportunities, sales quotes, sales orders, and production orders. Production transactions generate financial transactions indirectly through the Inventory module or directly in production management. You should review the Order Management with Inventory Configuration: General Information topic as a part of implementing manufacturing. Additionally, refer to System Preparation for Manufacturing Implementation: General Information. Manufacturing Checklists The following checklists are the mandatory and optional configuration steps for a successful implementation. Your Acumatica ERP license indicates which functionality you have. Inventory System Preparation for Manufacturing Implementation: Implementation ChecklistCore Manufacturing functionality Bill of Material: Implementation ChecklistProduction Management: Implementation ChecklistMRP: Implementation ChecklistOptional Manufacturing functionality Estimating: Implementation ChecklistProduct Configurator: Implementation Checklist

Before you start implementing the manufacturing functionality in Acumatica ERP, you need to prepare the system—that is, specify the general settings that will be used by particular manufacturing processes—as described in this topic.{br}{TOC} ==Learning Objectives== In this chapter, you will learn how to do the following:[anchor|#ul_dmx_2lv_pr] *Enable the needed set of features before you start implementing manufacturing *Specify the required settings to prepare the system for implementing manufacturing *Create stock items involved in manufacturing
==Applicable Scenarios== You configure general settings for manufacturing in either or bothof the following cases:[anchor|#_7165d0ed-fbf9-4bca-b563-a0155c7a9310] *When you are initially implementing Acumatica ERP and the ''Manufacturing'' feature is included in your license *When you have purchased the ''Manufacturing'' feature, and you need to configure manufacturing in the existing Acumatica ERP system
==Prerequisites== Before you start preparing the system to implementing manufacturing, you should make sure that the following criteria have been met:[anchor|#_65d9b147-f854-4845-907e-53bd3383928d] #The general ledger functionality has been configured, as described in [HelpRoot_Implement\config_GL_Generalinfo|General Ledger: General Information]. #Order and inventory management functionality have been configured. For details, see [HelpRoot_OrderMgmt\config_InvMgmt_Basic_Implem_Activity|Order Management with Inventory Configuration: Implementation Activity]. #For integration with projects, the project management functionality has been configured, as described in [HelpRoot_Projects\config_Project_Basic_GeneralInfo|Project Basic Configuration: General Information].
==System Preparation for Manufacturing Implementation== To implement the general configuration of manufacturing in Acumatica ERP, you perform the following steps:[anchor|#_abf24b25-ed60-4500-b22c-18208a979188] #On the [HelpRoot_FormReference\CS_10_00_00|Enable/Disable Features] ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) form, you make sure that the ''Manufacturing'' feature and all nested features that you will use in your system are enabled. #:((({S:Warn}In a production environment, after the features are enabled, you have to activate the Acumatica ERP license by using the [HelpRoot_FormReference\SM_20_15_10|Activate License] ([~/?ScreenId=SM201510|SM201510]) form. Each particular feature may be subject to additional licensing; please consult the Acumatica ERP sales policy for details. ))) #On the [HelpRoot_FormReference\CS_20_10_10|Numbering Sequences] ([~/?ScreenId=CS201010|CS201010]) form, you create the numbering sequences for manufacturing batches and entities. #On the [HelpRoot_FormReference\CS_10_15_00|Companies] ([~/?ScreenId=CS101500|CS101500]) form, you specify the number of decimal places for quantities and for prices and costs. #On the [HelpRoot_FormReference\GL_20_25_00|Chart of Accounts] ([~/?ScreenId=GL202500|GL202500]) form, you create the GL accounts to be used in manufacturing processes. #On the [HelpRoot_FormReference\IN_20_60_00|Posting Classes] ([~/?ScreenId=IN206000|IN206000]) form, you create the posting classes to be used for the inventory items involved in manufacturing. #On the [HelpRoot_FormReference\IN_20_15_00|Availability Calculation Rules] ([~/?ScreenId=IN201500|IN201500]) form, you specify the availability calculation rules for the stock items to be involved in manufacturing. #If the ''Inventory Replenishment'' feature (in the ''Inventory and Order Management'' group of features) is enabled on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\CS_10_00_00|Enable/Disable Features] form, on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\IN_20_88_00|Replenishment Classes] ([~/?ScreenId=IN208800|IN208800]) form, you create replenishment classes for items to be manufactured and purchased. If the feature is disabled, you specify replenishment settings for item classes, stock items, or both. #On the [HelpRoot_FormReference\IN_20_40_00|Warehouses] ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) form, you define the warehouses and locations that will be involved in manufacturing. #On the [HelpRoot_FormReference\IN_20_10_00|Item Classes] ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) form, you create the item classes that will provide the default settings for the stock items involved in manufacturing. #On the [HelpRoot_FormReference\IN_20_25_00|Stock Items] ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) form, you create the stock items to be used in manufacturing. #On the [HelpRoot_FormReference\IN_20_45_00|Item Warehouse Details] ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) form, for items involved in manufacturing that can be stored in multiple warehouses, you specify the item settings that are specific to a particular warehouse. #On the [HelpRoot_FormReference\EP_20_30_00|Employees] ([~/?ScreenId=EP203000|EP203000]) form, you specify the needed setting for employees that will be involved in production. #On the [HelpRoot_FormReference\SO_20_10_00|Order Types] ([~/?ScreenId=SO201000|SO201000]) form, you configure the sales order types that will be used in production management.
==Posting Settings== A variety of GL accounts must be created in the system on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\GL_20_25_00|Chart of Accounts] ([~/?ScreenId=GL202500|GL202500]) form and then specified on the forms that provide posting settings for transactions related to manufacturing processes. You need to create specific GL accounts and specify them in the system as follows:[anchor|#_aad30699-0ead-43d1-a823-1eaf0c912ee7] *You need to create the Work in Progress (WIP) account and the WIP Variance account, which are required for users to create production orders. The accounts should then be specified on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\IN_20_60_00|Posting Classes] ([~/?ScreenId=IN206000|IN206000]) form for the posting class; if posting classes are not used, the accounts should be specified on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_10_20_00|Production Preferences] ([~/?ScreenId=AM102000|AM102000]) form. For more information about posting classes, see [HelpRoot_InvMgmt\Posting_Classes_GeneralInfo|Posting Classes: General Information]. *You need to create a specific Labor account for labor expenses to be reported. Then you create a labor code by using the [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_20_65_00|Labor Codes] ([~/?ScreenId=AM206500|AM206500]) form and specify the corresponding account in the settings of this code. Labor codes are required when you create work centers on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_20_70_00|Work Centers] ([~/?ScreenId=AM207000|AM207000]) form. If indirect time will be reported according to the manufacturing processes of your organization, you can also create a GL account for indirect labor expense or you can use the same account as you use for direct labor. If you create a separate GL account for indirect labor expense, you also need to create a separate labor code. *If overhead, tooling, machine, or scrap costs are to be charged to production orders then you need to create a separate expense account to track each of these types of costs. The forms where you cpesify these accounts are the following: **[HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_20_25_00|Overhead] ([~/?ScreenId=AM202500|AM202500]): On this form, you specify the overhead GL account for each overhead. **[HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_20_45_00|Machines] ([~/?ScreenId=AM204500|AM204500]): On this form, you specify a GL account used for machine costs. **[HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_20_55_00|Tools] ([~/?ScreenId=AM205500|AM205500]): On this form, you specify a GL account used for tool costs. **[HelpRoot_FormReference\CS_21_10_00|Reason Codes] ([~/?ScreenId=CS211000|CS211000]): On this form, you create a reason code specifically for scrap and specify the GL account that will be used for scrap costs.
==Warehouse Settings== You need to define each warehouse and its locations where the stock items involved in manufacturing will be stored by using the [HelpRoot_FormReference\IN_20_40_00|Warehouses] ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) form. You may use an existing warehouse or create a separate one.{br}
You define a warehouse involved in manufacturing as follows:[anchor|#_1d98962d-5fcf-4650-9338-8d4c1b19cd7f] #On the '''Location Table''' tab, you define the locations that will be involved in manufacturing as follows: #*For each warehouse location that is used for planning purposes within material requirements planning (MRP), you select the '''MRP''' check box. #*For each location used for storing materials, you select the '''Sales Allowed''' and '''Assembly Allowed''' check boxes to indicate that this location can be used to issue items to production orders. #*For each location used for storing manufactured items, you select the '''Receipts Allowed''' and '''Assembly Allowed''' check boxes to indicate that this location can be used to receive items from production orders. #On the '''GL Accounts''' tab, you specify the '''Work in Progress''' and '''WIP Variance''' accounts. #In the '''General''' section of the '''Manufacturing''' tab, you select check boxes for the entities or documents to indicate which supply and demand are considered for this warehouse during material requirements planning. We recommend that all check boxes be selected in a production system.
For more information about warehouses and warehouse locations, see [HelpRoot_InvMgmt\Warehouses_GeneralInfo|Warehouses: General Information] and [HelpRoot_InvMgmt\Warehouse_Locations_GeneralInfo|Warehouse Locations and Single-Step Transfers: General Information]. ==Availability Calculation Settings== For each item to be added to manufacturing transactions, you need to specify whether it will be available for issuing. For this purpose, on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\IN_20_15_00|Availability Calculation Rules] ([~/?ScreenId=IN201500|IN201500]) form, you create or modify an availability calculation rule, in which you also select or clear check boxes for plan types related to manufacturing. You can include or deduct the quantities of items added to production orders in the available quantities of items.{br}
For details about availability calculation, see [HelpRoot_InvMgmt\Availability_Calculation_Rules_GeneralInfo|Availability Calculation Rules: General Information]. ==Replenishment Settings== To indicate that a stock item is manufactured and must be included in material requirements planning, you specify replenishment settings as follows:[anchor|#_f541be44-647a-401c-8d65-d22e2e850579] *If you use the replenishment functionality in Acumatica ERP—that is, the ''Inventory Replenishment'' feature is enabled on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\CS_10_00_00|Enable/Disable Features] ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) form—on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\IN_20_88_00|Replenishment Classes] ([~/?ScreenId=IN208800|IN208800]) form, you create two replenishment classes: one with a source of ''Purchase'' and another for a source of ''Manufacturing'', because these are the two key source types material requirements planning will use. Then you will specify the appropriate replenishment class, which depends on whether the item will be manufactured or purchased, in the replenishment settings of particular item classes, items, or both. *If the ''Inventory Replenishment'' feature is disabled, you select the needed replenishment source in the '''Replenishment Source''' box of the '''General Settings''' tab on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\IN_20_10_00|Item Classes] ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) for the item class or in the '''Source''' box on the '''Manufacturing''' tab of the [HelpRoot_FormReference\IN_20_25_00|Stock Items] ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) form for the item.
==Settings of Items Involved in Manufacturing== Items involved in manufacturing can be purchased (these items are usually components used in the production process) or manufactured (these items are usually the finished goods to be sold to customers). To provide default settings for groups of similar items, you create item classes on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\IN_20_10_00|Item Classes] ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) form. For each item class, you specify the following settings:[anchor|#_22536e35-0318-453c-82d8-8fece5eea892] *The posting class with the Work in Progress and WIP Variance GL accounts specified *The default warehouse where the items of the class will be stored *The availability calculation rule, which provides information for calculating the availability of items involved in manufacturing *Replenishment settings that indicate if items of the class will be produced or purchased
For more information about item classes, see [HelpRoot_InvMgmt\Item_Classes_GeneralInfo|Item Classes for Stock Items: General Information].{br}
Then on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\IN_20_25_00|Stock Items] ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) form, you create stock items; this process unfolds somewhat differently depending on whether the item is manufactured or purchased. For items being manufactured, you perform the following general steps:[anchor|#_c3777d49-4b53-4072-9c9a-0239a3dc85ad] #You select an item class that was created for items being manufactured. #If the ''Inventory Replenishment'' feature is enabled on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\CS_10_00_00|Enable/Disable Features] ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) form, on the '''Replenishment Info''' tab, you make sure that a replenishment class with the ''Manufacturing'' replenishment source has been added, and you specify the value of the '''Safety Stock''' box. This will set a certain level of inventory in the system to be planned for within material requirements planning. #If the ''Inventory Replenishment'' feature is disabled, in the '''Replenishments''' section of the '''Manufacturing''' tab, you make sure that the ''Manufacturing'' replenishment source is specified, and you add the value in the '''Safety Stock''' box. #In the '''General''' and '''Scheduling''' sections of the '''Manufacturing''' tab, you specify the needed settings.
For items being purchased, you perform the following general steps:[anchor|#_70624eba-4174-491c-a939-08904ec076c7] #You select an item class that was created for items being purchased. #On the '''Vendor Details''' tab, you specify the vendors from which the item will be purchased and make sure that the lead time is specified. The specification of the lead time is important so that during the material requirements planning process, personnel can consider this time when planning the supply. #On the '''Warehouse Details''' tab, you make sure that at least one warehouse is specified. #On the '''Price/Cost Info''' tab, specify the cost as follows, depending on the valuation method: For items with the ''Standard'' method, specify the cost in the '''Pending Cost''' box; for items with all other methods, specify the cost in the '''Last Cost''' box. #If the ''Inventory Replenishment'' feature is enabled on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\CS_10_00_00|Enable/Disable Features] form, on the '''Replenishment Info''' tab, you make sure that a replenishment class with the ''Purchase'' replenishment source has been added. #If the ''Inventory Replenishment'' feature is disabled, in the '''Replenishments''' section of the '''Manufacturing''' tab, you make sure that the ''Purchase'' replenishment source is specified. #In the '''General''' and '''Scheduling''' sections of the '''Manufacturing''' tab, you specify the needed settings.
For each item that has warehouse-specific settings, on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\IN_20_45_00|Item Warehouse Details] ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) form, you also need to do the following:[anchor|#_68f0a291-e151-4d27-bb58-4d50d6ce528b] #You make sure that warehouse locations are specified in the '''Default Receipt To''' and '''Default Issue From''' boxes, to make data entry easier for users. #If an item cost depends on the warehouse where the item is stored, on the '''Price/Cost Information''' tab, you enter a warehouse-specific cost for the item. #If the ''Inventory Replenishment'' feature is enabled on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\CS_10_00_00|Enable/Disable Features] form, on the '''Replenishment Info''' tab, you make sure that the replenishment class and the replenishment source are specified correctly. #If the ''Inventory Replenishment'' feature is disabled, in the '''Replenishments''' section of the '''Manufacturing''' tab, you make sure that the needed replenishment source is specified in the '''Source''' box.
==Settings of Employees Involved in Manufacturing== To record the labor expenses for employees involved in manufacturing, on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\EP_20_30_00|Employees] ([~/?ScreenId=EP203000|EP203000]) form, you select the '''Production Employee''' check box on the '''General Info''' tab.{br}
If you want to post labor transactions by using the employee cost, on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\PM_20_99_00|Labor Cost Rates] ([~/?ScreenId=PM209900|PM209900]) form, you create the needed cost rates and then specify a cost rate for each employee involved in manufacturing. ==Settings of Sales Documents== If the business process of your organization involves users creating production orders directly from sales orders, you must configure this functionality for each order type you use as follows: On the '''General Settings''' tab of the [HelpRoot_FormReference\SO_20_10_00|Order Types] ([~/?ScreenId=SO201000|SO201000]) form, you select either or both of the following check boxes: '''Allow Production Orders - Approve''' (which provides users with the ability to create production orders that have the ''Approved'' status from sales orders) and '''Allow Production Orders - Hold''' (which provides users with the ability to create production orders that have the ''On Hold'' status from sales orders) .{br}
Order types that typically used to create production orders are ''SO'' (a regular sales order), ''TR'' (a transfer order), and ''QT'' (a quote). For quotes, you can also select the '''Allow Estimating''' check box to allow estimate entries. ((({S:Warn}We do not recommend that you select this check box for other order types because estimates may include non-inventory items that cannot be shipped or issued. )))

System Preparation for Manufacturing Implementation: General Information Before you start implementing the manufacturing functionality in Acumatica ERP, you need to prepare the system—that is, specify the general settings that will be used by particular manufacturing processes—as described in this topic. Learning Objectives In this chapter, you will learn how to do the following: Enable the needed set of features before you start implementing manufacturing Specify the required settings to prepare the system for implementing manufacturing Create stock items involved in manufacturing Applicable Scenarios You configure general settings for manufacturing in either or bothof the following cases: When you are initially implementing Acumatica ERP and the Manufacturing feature is included in your license When you have purchased the Manufacturing feature, and you need to configure manufacturing in the existing Acumatica ERP system Prerequisites Before you start preparing the system to implementing manufacturing, you should make sure that the following criteria have been met: The general ledger functionality has been configured, as described in General Ledger: General Information. Order and inventory management functionality have been configured. For details, see Order Management with Inventory Configuration: Implementation Activity. For integration with projects, the project management functionality has been configured, as described in Project Basic Configuration: General Information. System Preparation for Manufacturing Implementation To implement the general configuration of manufacturing in Acumatica ERP, you perform the following steps: On the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form, you make sure that the Manufacturing feature and all nested features that you will use in your system are enabled. In a production environment, after the features are enabled, you have to activate the Acumatica ERP license by using the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201510|SM201510]) Activate License (SM201510) form. Each particular feature may be subject to additional licensing; please consult the Acumatica ERP sales policy for details. On the ([~/?ScreenId=CS201010|CS201010]) Numbering Sequences (CS201010) form, you create the numbering sequences for manufacturing batches and entities. On the ([~/?ScreenId=CS101500|CS101500]) Companies (CS101500) form, you specify the number of decimal places for quantities and for prices and costs. On the ([~/?ScreenId=GL202500|GL202500]) Chart of Accounts (GL202500) form, you create the GL accounts to be used in manufacturing processes. On the ([~/?ScreenId=IN206000|IN206000]) Posting Classes (IN206000) form, you create the posting classes to be used for the inventory items involved in manufacturing. On the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201500|IN201500]) Availability Calculation Rules (IN201500) form, you specify the availability calculation rules for the stock items to be involved in manufacturing. If the Inventory Replenishment feature (in the Inventory and Order Management group of features) is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features form, on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN208800|IN208800]) Replenishment Classes (IN208800) form, you create replenishment classes for items to be manufactured and purchased. If the feature is disabled, you specify replenishment settings for item classes, stock items, or both. On the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses (IN204000) form, you define the warehouses and locations that will be involved in manufacturing. On the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) Item Classes (IN201000) form, you create the item classes that will provide the default settings for the stock items involved in manufacturing. On the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form, you create the stock items to be used in manufacturing. On the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) form, for items involved in manufacturing that can be stored in multiple warehouses, you specify the item settings that are specific to a particular warehouse. On the ([~/?ScreenId=EP203000|EP203000]) Employees (EP203000) form, you specify the needed setting for employees that will be involved in production. On the ([~/?ScreenId=SO201000|SO201000]) Order Types (SO201000) form, you configure the sales order types that will be used in production management. Posting Settings A variety of GL accounts must be created in the system on the ([~/?ScreenId=GL202500|GL202500]) Chart of Accounts (GL202500) form and then specified on the forms that provide posting settings for transactions related to manufacturing processes. You need to create specific GL accounts and specify them in the system as follows: You need to create the Work in Progress (WIP) account and the WIP Variance account, which are required for users to create production orders. The accounts should then be specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN206000|IN206000]) Posting Classes (IN206000) form for the posting class; if posting classes are not used, the accounts should be specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM102000|AM102000]) Production Preferences (AM102000) form. For more information about posting classes, see Posting Classes: General Information. You need to create a specific Labor account for labor expenses to be reported. Then you create a labor code by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM206500|AM206500]) Labor Codes (AM206500) form and specify the corresponding account in the settings of this code. Labor codes are required when you create work centers on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM207000|AM207000]) Work Centers (AM207000) form. If indirect time will be reported according to the manufacturing processes of your organization, you can also create a GL account for indirect labor expense or you can use the same account as you use for direct labor. If you create a separate GL account for indirect labor expense, you also need to create a separate labor code. If overhead, tooling, machine, or scrap costs are to be charged to production orders then you need to create a separate expense account to track each of these types of costs. The forms where you cpesify these accounts are the following: ([~/?ScreenId=AM202500|AM202500]) Overhead (AM202500): On this form, you specify the overhead GL account for each overhead. ([~/?ScreenId=AM204500|AM204500]) Machines (AM204500): On this form, you specify a GL account used for machine costs. ([~/?ScreenId=AM205500|AM205500]) Tools (AM205500): On this form, you specify a GL account used for tool costs. ([~/?ScreenId=CS211000|CS211000]) Reason Codes (CS211000): On this form, you create a reason code specifically for scrap and specify the GL account that will be used for scrap costs. Warehouse Settings You need to define each warehouse and its locations where the stock items involved in manufacturing will be stored by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses (IN204000) form. You may use an existing warehouse or create a separate one. You define a warehouse involved in manufacturing as follows: On the Location Table tab, you define the locations that will be involved in manufacturing as follows: For each warehouse location that is used for planning purposes within material requirements planning (MRP), you select the MRP check box. For each location used for storing materials, you select the Sales Allowed and Assembly Allowed check boxes to indicate that this location can be used to issue items to production orders. For each location used for storing manufactured items, you select the Receipts Allowed and Assembly Allowed check boxes to indicate that this location can be used to receive items from production orders. On the GL Accounts tab, you specify the Work in Progress and WIP Variance accounts. In the General section of the Manufacturing tab, you select check boxes for the entities or documents to indicate which supply and demand are considered for this warehouse during material requirements planning. We recommend that all check boxes be selected in a production system. For more information about warehouses and warehouse locations, see Warehouses: General Information and Warehouse Locations and Single-Step Transfers: General Information. Availability Calculation Settings For each item to be added to manufacturing transactions, you need to specify whether it will be available for issuing. For this purpose, on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201500|IN201500]) Availability Calculation Rules (IN201500) form, you create or modify an availability calculation rule, in which you also select or clear check boxes for plan types related to manufacturing. You can include or deduct the quantities of items added to production orders in the available quantities of items. For details about availability calculation, see Availability Calculation Rules: General Information. Replenishment Settings To indicate that a stock item is manufactured and must be included in material requirements planning, you specify replenishment settings as follows: If you use the replenishment functionality in Acumatica ERP—that is, the Inventory Replenishment feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form—on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN208800|IN208800]) Replenishment Classes (IN208800) form, you create two replenishment classes: one with a source of Purchase and another for a source of Manufacturing , because these are the two key source types material requirements planning will use. Then you will specify the appropriate replenishment class, which depends on whether the item will be manufactured or purchased, in the replenishment settings of particular item classes, items, or both. If the Inventory Replenishment feature is disabled, you select the needed replenishment source in the Replenishment Source box of the General Settings tab on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) Item Classes (IN201000) for the item class or in the Source box on the Manufacturing tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form for the item . Settings of Items Involved in Manufacturing Items involved in manufacturing can be purchased (these items are usually components used in the production process) or manufactured (these items are usually the finished goods to be sold to customers). To provide default settings for groups of similar items, you create item classes on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) Item Classes (IN201000) form. For each item class, you specify the following settings: The posting class with the Work in Progress and WIP Variance GL accounts specified The default warehouse where the items of the class will be stored The availability calculation rule, which provides information for calculating the availability of items involved in manufacturing Replenishment settings that indicate if items of the class will be produced or purchased For more information about item classes, see Item Classes for Stock Items: General Information. Then on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form, you create stock items; this process unfolds somewhat differently depending on whether the item is manufactured or purchased. For items being manufactured, you perform the following general steps: You select an item class that was created for items being manufactured. If the Inventory Replenishment feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form, on the Replenishment Info tab, you make sure that a replenishment class with the Manufacturing replenishment source has been added, and you specify the value of the Safety Stock box. This will set a certain level of inventory in the system to be planned for within material requirements planning. If the Inventory Replenishment feature is disabled, in the Replenishments section of the Manufacturing tab, you make sure that the Manufacturing replenishment source is specified, and you add the value in the Safety Stock box. In the General and Scheduling sections of the Manufacturing tab, you specify the needed settings. For items being purchased, you perform the following general steps: You select an item class that was created for items being purchased. On the Vendor Details tab, you specify the vendors from which the item will be purchased and make sure that the lead time is specified. The specification of the lead time is important so that during the material requirements planning process, personnel can consider this time when planning the supply. On the Warehouse Details tab, you make sure that at least one warehouse is specified. On the Price/Cost Info tab, specify the cost as follows, depending on the valuation method: For items with the Standard method, specify the cost in the Pending Cost box; for items with all other methods, specify the cost in the Last Cost box. If the Inventory Replenishment feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features form, on the Replenishment Info tab, you make sure that a replenishment class with the Purchase replenishment source has been added. If the Inventory Replenishment feature is disabled, in the Replenishments section of the Manufacturing tab, you make sure that the Purchase replenishment source is specified. In the General and Scheduling sections of the Manufacturing tab, you specify the needed settings. For each item that has warehouse-specific settings, on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) form, you also need to do the following: You make sure that warehouse locations are specified in the Default Receipt To and Default Issue From boxes, to make data entry easier for users. If an item cost depends on the warehouse where the item is stored, on the Price/Cost Information tab, you enter a warehouse-specific cost for the item. If the Inventory Replenishment feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features form, on the Replenishment Info tab, you make sure that the replenishment class and the replenishment source are specified correctly. If the Inventory Replenishment feature is disabled, in the Replenishments section of the Manufacturing tab, you make sure that the needed replenishment source is specified in the Source box. Settings of Employees Involved in Manufacturing To record the labor expenses for employees involved in manufacturing, on the ([~/?ScreenId=EP203000|EP203000]) Employees (EP203000) form, you select the Production Employee check box on the General Info tab. If you want to post labor transactions by using the employee cost, on the ([~/?ScreenId=PM209900|PM209900]) Labor Cost Rates (PM209900) form, you create the needed cost rates and then specify a cost rate for each employee involved in manufacturing. Settings of Sales Documents If the business process of your organization involves users creating production orders directly from sales orders, you must configure this functionality for each order type you use as follows: On the General Settings tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=SO201000|SO201000]) Order Types (SO201000) form, you select either or both of the following check boxes: Allow Production Orders - Approve (which provides users with the ability to create production orders that have the Approved status from sales orders) and Allow Production Orders - Hold (which provides users with the ability to create production orders that have the On Hold status from sales orders) . Order types that typically used to create production orders are SO (a regular sales order), TR (a transfer order), and QT (a quote). For quotes, you can also select the Allow Estimating check box to allow estimate entries . We do not recommend that you select this check box for other order types because estimates may include non-inventory items that cannot be shipped or issued.

System Preparation for Manufacturing Implementation: Implementation Checklist The following sections provide details you can use to ensure that the system is configured properly for implementing manufacturing. Implementation Checklist We recommend that before you start configuring manufacturing-specific settings, you make sure the needed features have been enabled, settings have been specified, and entities have been created, as summarized in the following checklist. Manufacturing Overview The Manufacturing edition of Acumatica ERP deliver powerful and comprehensive functionality for make-to-stock, make-to-order, engineer-to-order, project-centric, job shop, batch, and repetitive manufacturing companies. It is an easy-to-use and powerful solution designed to be used by a wide range of organizations with simple to advanced business flow and reporting needs. In this topic, you will find information about parts of Manufacturing edition. Bills of Material The Bills of Material (BOM)/Routing part creates production specifications and is the framework for the planning functionality in all Manufacturing edition parts. Maintenance of the BOM/Routing information is performed through a single form. You directly connect materials, work instructions, tools, attributes, and overhead costs to an operation. It provides for revision tracking, phantom assemblies, backflushing of both labor and materials, material effectivity dates, by-products, and alternate bills of materials. For more information, see Bills of Material: General Information. Production Management The Production Management part provides you with easy entry of production orders, quick release of planned production orders, availability of using alternate BOMs and routing by using revisions, an event history, and easy release of materials. For details, see Production Management: General InformationMaterial Requirements Planning (MRP) The Material Requirements Planning (MRP) part provides you with the ability to schedule full regeneration for planning what materials will be need to be purchased or produced, as well as plan production and purchase orders. For more information, see Material Requirements Planning: General Information. Estimating The optional Estimating part is integrated with manufacturing, customer management, and sales orders. It provides users with the ability to create quick and detailed manufacturing estimates for improved estimate accuracy and turnaround times. Users can accurately calculate costs and prices for new or existing parts using material costs, work center rates, overheads, and other data. For details, see Estimating: General Information. Product Configurator The optional Product Configurator part is integrated with manufacturing, customer management, and sales orders. It is a rule-based system designed to provide users the ability to configure, order, and build to order inventory items. For details, see Product Configurator: General Information. Advanced Planning and Scheduling The optional Advanced Planning and Scheduling (APS) part provides the ability to finitely schedule production orders based on work center capacity. This functionality extends the production management functionality. For details, see Advanced Planning and Scheduling: General Information. Engineering Change Control The optional Engineering Change Control (ECC) part provides a workflow process to approve and update bills of material. This feature extends the bills of material functionality. For more information, see Engineering Change Control: General Information.

Backflushing Concepts The production management functionality supports the backflushing of both materials and labor. The defaults are defined in the bill of material using ([~/?ScreenId=AM208000|AM208000]) Bill of Material (AM208000) which defaults for each operation from the work center settings when creating the bill. Flexibility is provided by configuring backflushing for only specific materials and/or operations. The configuration of backflushing starts with the work center. You can check the Backflush Materials and/or Backflush Labor for a work center by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM207000|AM207000]) Work Centers (AM207000) form to provide default values for operations added to a bill of material. When you add an operation to the bill of material you can select or clear the backflush option for labor and/or material. When you add the materials for an operation you can select or clear the backflush option for any material. When you report production for an operation by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM301000|AM301000]) Labor (AM301000) or ([~/?ScreenId=AM302000|AM302000]) Move (AM302000) form and a quantity is entered, the following occurs: Any materials where the backlashed flag is checked will be issued to the production order from the warehouse/location specified in the material line or if empty from the default issue from warehouse/location. The How Warehouse Locations Are Selected topic explains how locations are determined. If there are prior operations with backflush checked for materials, the quantity to issue is calculated as the difference between the actual quantity reported at that operation and this operation multiplied by the quantity per. This can result is a negative issue if the prior operation had material issued. If there are prior operations with the backflush labor checked the labor amount will be adjusted if necessary to agree with the quantity reported at the current operation vs. the quantity previously reported. The purpose of the recalculations is to reconcile any quantity differences between the current operation and any prior operations and adjust the costs charged to the production order accordingly. If you decide to backflush materials, please note the following: The process creates a Materials batch on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM300000|AM300000]) Materials (AM300000) form, which is automatically released. It cannot issue more materials than what is on hand in a location unless negative inventories are allowed. The locations are determined according the rules specified in How Warehouse Locations Are Selected. What is Backflushing? Backflushing is a method for issuing materials and/or labor to production orders at the point that production of a specific operation is reported. This is commonly referred to as "postproduction issuing" , vs. "preproduction issuing" where materials are pulled from stores and issued to production orders prior to the start of an operation and labor is directly reported for each operation. Material and labor costs are flushed backwards through operations to assign costs to products based on the quantity of product produced at the operations. The result is that detailed tracking of costs is eliminated. This can represent a time savings over the traditional method of a) issuing component parts one at a time, b) reporting operation labor or quantities, and c) returning any unused components, one at a time, back into inventory. Additionally, backflushing can ensure that the full cost of production is recognized when the final operation is reported and the finished product is received into inventory. The backflushing process will adjust the materials consumed and/or labor reported for any operations where the full amount has not been posted. The receipt cost of the product can be more representative and/or variances are minimized. When is Backflushing Appropriate? In operations where scrap is common in the finished item and you continue to produce until you have a good quantity equal to the ordered quantity. You would report both the good quantity and scrap quantity to ensure the proper quantities of materials and labor. Only certain milestone operations are reported and prior operations are backflushed to account for the labor cost. Or inspection operations are performed by sampling. Operations are performed for multiple production orders at the simultaneously or in a continuous run such as cleaning, painting, plating, etc. where it would be difficult to post labor to individual orders. Similarly, there may be production areas or lines where multiple operators work on whatever item appears at their work station such as filling, testing, packing, or assembly and do not report their time against specific orders. There are floor stock items, such as lubricants, labels, hardware, wiring, packing materials, etc., in the bill of material whose costs are not significant. An expense issue is performed periodically to reconcile the on hand balance to the physical inventory. When you use point-of-use materials, backflushing simplifies the issuing process and makes it easier to perform counts on the point-of-use materials. If you were to preproduction issue these materials you would need to reconcile the inventory balances with any orders that had quantities staged to the production area but not yet consumed, however, if by backflushing you should have a system-to-actual-count match after each production posting. In very long production runs (days or weeks) where preproduction posting takes the materials out of the on-hand inventory balance days or weeks before they are being used and puts the dollar value into a WIP account for the production order. You also may have situations where you do not have enough of the raw materials for the entire production run, however, more will be arriving during the run. When you are using bulk materials such as bar stock, roll stock, sheet goods, and dry goods or liquids in bulk containers, where the exact quantity cannot be picked. For example, if you need 1000 linear feet of material that comes in bulk rolls of 300 linear feet, preproduction issuing of 1000 even though the material handler delivered 1200 causes a confusing inventory situation, and issuing the entire 1200 would require you to reverse issue 200 when you return the remainder. When is Backflushing Not Appropriate? The amount of labor applied to an operation can have variances from one production run to another. The labor amount may represent a significant cost of the product. When employees are accountable for the product being produced and traceability is desired. Lot and/or serialized materials must be verified and recorded as being issued. Although backflushing can automatically issue lot- or serial-tracked items it is generally not recommended. Materials consumption is variable or there is significant waste of a particular material. Material substitutions are common and allowed during the production process. Labor transactions by employee need to be reconciled to time and attendance for payroll purposes or a shop data collection system is used. When you have materials stored in multiple physical bin locations there is guarantee material was picked from the backflush location.

By-Products By-products are secondary products from the manufacturing process for the primary product. If you are going to use lot control for by-products and you are going to backflush them, you must set up the lot class for sequential issue. If you do not wish to have a cost for the by-product credited to the primary product cost, then set the valuation method of the by-product to Standard Cost and set a standard cost of zero or make sure not to do any receipts for the by-product with a cost for average, FIFO, or specific cost. Setting up the Bill of Material for By-Products Any material component with a negative quantity required is considered a by-product. The cost of a by-product is credited to the cost of the primary product if the by-product has a cost. For example: Component Qty Required Unit Cost CHEMCOMP1 .05 Liters 1.00 CHEMCOMP2 .06 Liters 1.00 CHENBYPROD1 -.01 Liters 1.00 The material cost per liter is $1.00: (.05 x $1.00) + (.06 x $1.00) + (-.01 x $1.00). By-Products and Production Orders When a production order is created, any items with a negative quantity per unit required will have the by-product flag checked. Similarly, you must enter a negative quantity per unit required for a by-product you add to a production order manually. The cost of the by-product, if any, is calculated and deducted from the planned material and total cost of the production order when creating the production order. The by-product flag on the production details is used when creating a materials batch to indicate that this item will be received into inventory. An Inventory Receipt transaction is created to receive the by-product into inventory. The receipt cost of a by-product is determined using the Item Warehouse cost; this is the same method used to determine the cost of all materials. The by-product is not credited with any of the production costs. This is generally accepted method for handling by-products. When compared to the main products, because they are deemed to have no influence on reported financial results, by-products do not receive allocations of joint costs. By-products also by convention are not inventoried, but the NRV from by-products is typically recognized as other income or as a reduction of joint production processing costs when the by-product is produced. A by-product can be useful and marketable or it can be considered waste. This information has been copied from the following sources: Wouters, Mark; Selto, Frank H.; Hilton, Ronald W.; Maher, Michael W. (2012): Cost Management: Strategies for Business Decisions , International Edition, McGraw-Hill, p. 535. World Trade Organization (2004): United States - Final dumping determination on softwood lumber from Canada, WT/DS264/AB/R, 11 August 2004.

The bill of material structure has been completely redesigned. In prior releases of the Manufacturing Edition each bill of material header and details records had '''Effective Start Date''' and '''Effective End Date''' columns that were controlled by the application. With revisions, the start and end dates for the bill of material header are informational only and can be maintained by the user without restrictions. As a result of this new design revision is now a required field. ==Advantages of Using Revisions for Bills of Material== The advantages of this change include:[anchor|#_8147a0d8-9da0-4f29-9a7a-26ddd6b3144a] *The most recent active revision is the default for production orders and MRP planning. The ''Effective Start Date'' and ''Effective End Date'' for material records are still available and are used to determine which components are selected for orders and planning based on the order or operation start date. *:((({S:Warn}The most recent revision is the first revision sorted descending. ))) *Better synchronization with external PDM systems and drawings. *Revision is now a required entry and the option to ''Track Revision History'' is removed. *User control of which bills are active and available for use. *Only bills of material revisions ''On Hold'' can be updated. **A revision can have a status of ''Hold'', ''Active'', or ''Archived''. **The revision status can be changed at any time. **Multiple revisions can be active at the same time. *Creating a new revision of a bill copies the entire bill including all attributes, notes, and attachments. The copy is based on the most recently created revision. *A revision can be deleted only when it is not the source for a production order, product configuration, or referenced on a bill of material or production material.
==Archiving Bills of Material== Archiving a bill of material sets the '''End Date''' to the current business date and removes it from the boxes used to select bills of material in other modules. You can select the '''Hold''' check box for a revision with a status of ''Archived'' to make it editable again. Once edited, clearing the '''Hold''' check box changes the status to ''Active''. ==Form and Report Changes== The '''Revision ID''' has been added as a required entry, selection, or column to the following forms and reports.[anchor|#_ae30f38d-939b-481b-85a7-4559870ad559] *Forms **[HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_20_80_00|Bill of Material] **[HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_20_85_00|BOM Attributes] **[HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_50_80_00|Cost Roll] **[HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_50_90_00|Mass Change] **[HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_40_20_00|Where Used] **[HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_10_10_00|BOM Preferences] **[HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_20_15_00|Production Order Maintenance] **[HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_20_90_00|Production Order Details] **[HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_20_75_00|Configuration Maintenance] **[HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_30_30_00|Estimate] *Reports **[HelpRoot_ReportReference\AM_61_10_00|BOM Summary] **[HelpRoot_ReportReference\AM_41_30_00|Multi Level BOM] **[HelpRoot_ReportReference\AM_61_20_00|BOM Routing]

Bill of Material Revisions The bill of material structure has been completely redesigned. In prior releases of the Manufacturing Edition each bill of material header and details records had Effective Start Date and Effective End Date columns that were controlled by the application. With revisions, the start and end dates for the bill of material header are informational only and can be maintained by the user without restrictions. As a result of this new design revision is now a required field. Advantages of Using Revisions for Bills of Material The advantages of this change include: The most recent active revision is the default for production orders and MRP planning. The Effective Start Date and Effective End Date for material records are still available and are used to determine which components are selected for orders and planning based on the order or operation start date. The most recent revision is the first revision sorted descending. Better synchronization with external PDM systems and drawings. Revision is now a required entry and the option to Track Revision History is removed. User control of which bills are active and available for use. Only bills of material revisions On Hold can be updated. A revision can have a status of Hold , Active , or Archived . The revision status can be changed at any time. Multiple revisions can be active at the same time. Creating a new revision of a bill copies the entire bill including all attributes, notes, and attachments. The copy is based on the most recently created revision. A revision can be deleted only when it is not the source for a production order, product configuration, or referenced on a bill of material or production material. Archiving Bills of Material Archiving a bill of material sets the End Date to the current business date and removes it from the boxes used to select bills of material in other modules. You can select the Hold check box for a revision with a status of Archived to make it editable again. Once edited, clearing the Hold check box changes the status to Active . General Ledger Integration These are the accounts, and if configured, subaccounts used on the manufacturing forms specified directly or indirectly. General Ledger Accounts Used in Manufacturing The work in process (WIP) account and subaccount and the WIP Variance account and subaccount are required in order to create production orders and are specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN206000|IN206000]) Posting Classes (IN206000) form or if not used, then on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM102000|AM102000]) Production Preferences (AM102000) form. The Work in Progress account should be of the Asset type and the WIP Variance should be of the Expense type. This account should not be used as an inventory or expense account in order to be able to balance the account in the ([~/?ScreenId=AM654000|AM654000]) Work in Process (AM654000) report. Transactions for production orders debit the work in process account and credit the offset account for each cost element. A reversing transaction does the opposite. Upon closing a production order the WIP Variance account is posted and the WIP Balance is zeroed and the appropriate debit and credit generated. At this time the Control Account validation feature is not supported when specifying the accounts on manufacturing forms. If production scrap will be reported and expensed, then you need to specify the appropriate reason codes on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS211000|CS211000]) Reason Codes (CS211000) form with their GL accounts for the scrap expense. For more details, see Handling Production Scrap and Waste. Labor codes must also be set up by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM206500|AM206500]) Labor Codes (AM206500) form. Labor codes are required when setting up work cnters on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM207000|AM207000]) Work Centers (AM207000) form. If indirect time will be reported, then an indirect labor account is also required or you may use the same account as for direct labor. If overhead, tooling, r machine costs are to be charged to production orders then each requires an offset account to be defined on the following forms: ([~/?ScreenId=AM202500|AM202500]) Overhead (AM202500) ([~/?ScreenId=AM205500|AM205500]) Tools (AM205500) ([~/?ScreenId=AM204500|AM204500]) Machines (AM204500) You need to consider the impact of posting to the non-inventory accounts (labor, overhead, machines, and tooling) in production management. Typically, the actual manufacturing expenses such payroll and benefits, utilities, depreciation, purchased tooling, repairs and maintenance, etc. are posted to the General Ledger into cost of sales accounts. The labor, overhead, tools, and/or machine accounts could be set up as balance sheet accrual accounts or income statement contra expense accounts that would be debited to zero when posting the actual costs. In the following table, you can view the list of GL accounts used in manufacturing. Category Debit Account Credit Account Bill of Material Direct Labor (WIP Account) Labor Account Indirect Indirect Labor Expense Labor Account Overhead (WIP Account) Overhead Account Tools (WIP Account) Tooling Account Machine (WIP Account) Machine Account Production Management Work in Process WIP Account (Inventory) or expense WIP Variance WIP Variance WIP Account The Inventory account and subaccount is copied from the stock item's Inventory account when material is issued or received; if the item issued is non-stock, then the Expense Accrual account is used. Labor expense is copied from the account and subaccount specified for the labor code; other costs that are automatically calculated such as overhead, tooling, or machine costs, use the expense account specified. If labor is backflushed, then the labor expense account is copied from the labor code associated with the first shift code of the work center specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM207000|AM207000]) Work Centers (AM207000) form.

Handling Production Scrap and Waste Waste is a loss of materials inputted into the production process and is specified by the Scrap Factor assigned to the material in the bill of material. For example, during the cutting of a material 5% waste is expected. The quantity, and resultant total cost, of a material required is scaled up by the scrap factor. The wasted material does not have value although some costs may be recovered if the waste can be recycled such as metal filings, wood chips, and plastics. By-products are also production output and are typically treated as waste because production costs are not allocated to them. They can, however, have a standard cost which is used to credit the production order with their value when received into inventory. Scrap is a loss from production output; that is the item being produced does not meet its specifications. In this case, the scrap can have a value representing the accrued production costs. The item may be reworked to meet specifications, sold as-is at a discounted price, used as input to another process, or discarded. Options for Scrap Accounting There are the following methods available to account for the cost of production scrap (for details, see Scrap Processing Configuration): No Action : The cost of scrap remains in the production order and no scrap transaction is generated Write-off : The cost is written off and charged to an expense account Quarantine : The scrap is received into inventory to a quarantined location and dispositioned later The Include Scrap in Completions check box on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM102000|AM102000]) Production Preferences (AM102000) form is still used to determine if an operation is closed automatically. The receipt cost calculation ignores the total scrap for all scrap that has been written off and will not include those quantities in the receipt cost calculation. If scrap is not written off, then the scrap quantity is included or excluded based on the setting. In the latter two methods, the cost of the scrap is the accrued production cost which debits the scrap expense account and credits the work in process account of the production order. If the quarantine option is used, the inventory on hand balance is adjusted at the quarantine warehouse and location; the Ext. Cost is the calculated scrap cost. Negative scrap, typically to correct a transaction, is permitted and the transactions have the opposite effect. The actual transactions are generated on the following forms: ([~/?ScreenId=AM308000|AM308000]) WIP Adjustment (AM308000): On this form, a GL transaction is generated to credit the production order WIP account and debit the Scrap Expense account specified by the reason code. The WIP adjustment is recorded on the Production Order Events tab. ([~/?ScreenId=IN303000|IN303000]) Adjustments (IN303000): Additionally, if the scrap action is Quarantine , an inventory adjustment is created and released. The GL transaction created by the adjustment debits the Inventory account and credits the Scrap Expense account. If the stock item has a valuation method of standard cost, then an inventory account is posted at standard cost and the standard cost adjustment is generated for the difference; the credit for scrap expense is the actual cost. The costs calculated for negative scrap may differ from the original transaction if additional costs have been posted to the operations used to calculate the cost. Impact on Inventory Valuation If you choose to use the scrap action of Quarantine the inventory adjustment will update the current cost. For this reason we recommend that you either create a separate warehouse, or select the Cost Separately check box for the warehouse location, for the quarantined inventory to ensure the scrap cost does not affect the cost of accepted inventory when the item valuation method is FIFO or Average Cost . If the item valuation method is Standard , you select the Override Standard Cost check box on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) form. If the item valuation method is Specific , then you can use the same warehouse however, the last cost and average cost values will still include the scrap cost adjustment. Scrap Cost Calculation The scrap cost calculations are dependent on the costing method specified for the production order. Actual Costing Method To calculate the actual cost of scrap, the cost of each production operation is calculated. The cost of the scrap includes the actual costs for the current operation for which scrap is reported plus the estimated costs of prior operations. The estimated costs for prior operations is the sum of actual plus planned costs to account for materials, labor, and other costs not reported; that is a material was not issued to a prior operation so its planned unit cost will be factored into the operation cost totals. The WIP balance for each operation is the total actual costs posted minus the MFG to Inventory (that is, the total costs of receipts to inventory) totals. The formula used for calculation of each operation is the following: AMProdOper.WIPBalance / (AMProdOper.QtyComplete + AMProdOper.QtyScrapped - AMProdItem.QtyComplete) * AMMTran.QtyScrapped AMProdOper.QtyComplete includes the adjusted amount for transaction move quantity or scrap. Estimated or Standard Costing Method The only difference between these costing methods and the Actual costing method is these methods will factor in the planned costs to the WIP Balance for missing costs; such as labor or materials overhead that have not been reported. For example, all of the materials needed to produce the item at an operation were not issued. Processing Scrap in Production Transactions You can enter the scrapped quantity to both the labor and move transactions. When the Qty Scrapped is not 0 and the scrap action is not No Action , a WIP adjustment transaction is created for the scrap cost. The Orig Batch Nbr and Orig Doc Type link back to the source transaction. The reason code entered determines the Scrap Expense account and subaccount. The table with details include the production order values for the operation, scrap quantity, and any inventory adjustment created. The scrap warehouse and scrap location are defaulted from the production order. A GL transaction is created when the WIP adjustment is released to post to the scrap expense production order WIP account. If the scrap action is Quarantine you must enter the move or labor transaction on a separate line and select the Is Scrap check box. This is required in order to specify the scrap warehouse, location, and if required, the lot/serial number. Reporting Options To create an inquiry or report for the scrap activity the AMTran Data Access Class will have the DocType set to W and the TranType set to either of the following: XSW : Scrap Write-Off XSQ : Scrap Quarantine

([~/?ScreenId=AM201100|AM201100]) Production Order Types (AM201100), the General Settings tab. Scrap Source The scrap source determines the default values for the Scrap Warehouse and Scrap Location boxes when a production order is created on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201500|AM201500]) Production Order Maintenance (AM201500) form. The default values for the Scrap Warehouse and Scrap Location boxes of a production order are copied as follows: If the scrap source is None , no default values are used. If the scrap source is Item , the scrap warehouse and scrap location are copied from the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) form. If the values on this form are empty, the system uses the values from the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form. How Batch Sizes and Quantity Round Up are Used A new method to calculate requirements for inventory items has been added. This enhancement affects all forms and processes where material quantities are calculated; bills of material, production orders, MRP, estimates, and options for product configurations. Quantity Round Up On the Manufacturing tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form, the Forecast Round Up check box has been replaced with the Quantity Round Up check box, which is cleared by default. The purpose is to round up any calculations of the quantity required to the next integer value. This is particularly useful for inventory items stocked in units without decimals such as Each or Unit . The round up is applied to the unit of measure specified for the requirement; that is, if the base stocking unit is ounce and pound is specified as the unit of measure for a production order, then the requirement is rounded up the next pound. Batch Size The batch size is also used in calculating the quantity required for inventory items. Previously, all material requirements were specified as per unit of the parent item. With the batch size supported, now the quantity required can be calculated as per lot size of the parent. As with quantity round up, batch size is used on all calculations of inventory quantities required. The lot size term refers to the quantity of the parent inventory item being produced. The parent lot size is set on the Manufacturing tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form and can be overridden on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) form. The lot size becomes the default for MRP planned orders and production orders and is used in the cost roll process of the ([~/?ScreenId=AM508000|AM508000]) Cost Roll (AM508000) form. On the ([~/?ScreenId=AM303000|AM303000]) Estimate (AM303000) form, the Order Qty on the Totals tab is used as the lot size. The quantity to produce is the lot size for production orders and the materials required are calculated on that basis. Changing the quantity to produce recalculates the requirements. Batch size settings are the following: Batch Size of One (1): The quantity required of a component is per unit of the parent inventory item. This is the default value. Batch Size of Zero (0): The quantity required is fixed regardless of the parent lot size. Batch Size Greater than One (1): The quantity required is divided by the batch size. Added Calculation Columns In the following table, you can view columns that have been added where appropriate to assist users in visualizing the effect of the batch size and quantity round up functionality. Qty Remaining (Operations) Calculated as Total Qty minus Qty Complete Total Required The quantity of a material required based on the Batch Size and Quantity Round Up values. Qty Remaining (Materials) Calculated as Total Required minus Qty Actual . Total Quantity Required Examples The examples below show the effect of the batch size and quantity round up functionality. Importing Master Data into Manufacturing You can import master data related to manufacturing by using import scenarios on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM206036|SM206036]) Import by Scenario (SM206036) form. In this topic, you will find information that will help you to import data. Also, you will find the Excel spreadsheets that you can use during import. The format of all time values (Setup, Run, Machine, and Move) is specified in the Operation Time Format box on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM101000|AM101000]) BOM Preferences form. Times are now entered or displayed as in days, hours, and minutes. Regardless of the format, you can enter the time as 0000 for HHMM or 000000 for DDHHMM. Time values are actually stored as minutes in the tables. For importing, enter the time as HHMM; e,g. 0010 for 10 minutes, 0130 for 1 hour 30 minutes, 011013 for 1 day, 10 hours, 13 minutes. General Information Almost all of the master data is related to bills of material functionality consisting of the bills of material for each assembly and their supporting data such as work centers, tools, machines, and overhead. For details, see Importing Bills of Material Master Data. Data providers and import scenarios are provided for each of the following; the provider and scenario have the same name and all use Excel as the provider type. The sample Excel files are provided at the end of this topic. You should import your data in the same order as in the following table. Master Data Form Provider / Import Scenario ([~/?ScreenId=AM204500|AM204500]) Machines (AM204500) Import Machines ([~/?ScreenId=AM205500|AM205500]) Tools (AM205500) Import Tools ([~/?ScreenId=AM207000|AM207000]) Work Centers (AM207000) Import Work Centers ([~/?ScreenId=AM208000|AM208000]) Bill of Material (AM208000) Import BOM Additionally, you must specify BOM preferences on the BOM Preferences () form and enter the following required data first in order to import work centers. Required Data The following data is required even if you do not intend to include labor and indirect costs for your bills of material and to post them to production orders: ([~/?ScreenId=CS209000|CS209000]) Work Calendar (CS209000): Defines the hours available per day and is used to calculate both fixed and variable lead times in MRP and Production Management. You enter the calendar to use for shifts of a work center, for fixed lead times in Production Preferences, and for purchasing in MRP Preferences. ([~/?ScreenId=AM205000|AM205000]) Shifts (AM205000): Machines are used to factor labor rates. ([~/?ScreenId=AM206500|AM206500]) Labor Codes (AM206500): Define the GL accounts and subaccounts for direct and indirect labor expense. Data providers and import scenarios are not supplied for Shifts , Labor Codes , or Overhead since most users will have only a few of each. If you need to create one, then enter one of each type on the appropriate form and export the data to Excel. You then can use that spreadsheet to create the data provider and import scenario since it will have all of the columns available and the correct values for drop-down lists and check boxes. In Acumatica ERP, you enter the drop-down list caption and not codes and either True (selected) or False (cleared) for check boxes. Your reseller can assist you in creating data providers and import scenarios. Optional Data The following data are completely optional: ([~/?ScreenId=AM205500|AM205500]) Tools (AM205500): Can be entered as an additional cost element in a bill of material ([~/?ScreenId=AM204500|AM204500]) Machines (AM204500): Can be entered as an additional cost element for work centers ([~/?ScreenId=AM202500|AM202500]) Overhead (AM202500): Can be entered as an additional cost element for both work centers and bills of material. Once you have entered the required and optional data the next step is to create or import your work centers. In bills of material, components, as wells as tools, are tied to operations and operations require a work center.
