Lead Time Concepts Lead times are used to indicate when an action needs to take place. For example, the required date for a purchase order is offset by the lead time to determine when the action date when a purchase order should be placed. Vendor lead times in Acumatica ERP are in calendar days. The working days, used for manufactured items are configured by using the ([~/?ScreenId=CS209000|CS209000]) Work Calendar (CS209000) form. There can be multiple work calendars each with different time zones, working hours, and exceptions. An exception would be making a calendar holiday a non-working day or the reverse of making a weekend date a working day. Lead Time Components Your lead time should account for the total time it takes when you recognize a demand to the when the item is available to be shipped. This would include the time necessary to review requirements, source and select how it will be acquired (for example, do you find potential suppliers and get quotes, or does engineering need to review it?), prepare a requisition if necessary, obtain approval, create the order, send it to supplier or plant, vendor/factory production time, transport time from supplier/plant to distribution point, receiving and inspection. The purpose of a lead time is to provide you with sufficient time to source purchased items or to start and complete production processes in order to satisfy customer demand. Padding lead times with excessive days may lead to placing or starting orders too far in advance and do not necessarily improve on-time delivery or completion performance. How Manufacturing Uses Calendars with Lead Times There are multiple forms (listed below) where you select a working calendar to use. When computing dates, the appropriate calendar is used. Bill of Material ([~/?ScreenId=AM207000|AM207000]) Work Centers (AM207000): The calendar is used to determine the working days available hours each day and is used when calculating operation planned start and completion dates for variable lead times. Production Management ([~/?ScreenId=AM102000|AM102000]) Production Preferences (AM102000): You can specify a global calendar to use to fixed manufacturing lead times and indicate if you will set manufacturing fixed lead times to be hours or days. ([~/?ScreenId=AM201500|AM201500]) Production Order Maintenance (AM201500): You can decide whether to use fixed manufacturing days for an individual production order Material Requirements Planning ([~/?ScreenId=AM100000|AM100000]) MRP Preferences (AM100000): A calendar is specified to be used for purchase orders. Purchase Lead Times Purchase lead time are always fixed and not variable by order quantity so you should set them based on a typical order size. The lead times for items having a replenishment source of Purchasing use the lead time from the default vendor location which can be adjusted for a specific item and warehouse. If an item does not have a default vendor the lead time from the Manufacturing tab is used. For example, the lead time for a vendor location is 10 calendar days but certain items may need additional 5 days or require 5 less days. The MRP Regeneration process uses the purchase lead time to calculate the action date; if the action date is not a working day in the purchase palendar, the action date is moved back to the first working day. The vendor lead time and purchase calendar are used for all purchase orders, including those created by the Critical Materials process in production management, is set on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM100000|AM100000]) MRP Preferences (AM100000) form. Manufacturing Lead Times In both MRP and production management, you can choose to use fixed or variable lead times. When using fixed lead times, you must specify a work calendar to use so that dates will only fall on a working day. If you use variable lead times, then both will use the routing operation times in hours to calculate the planned starting and ending dates. With fixed lead times used for production orders, all operations will start or end on the corresponding start or end dates for the production order. Operation lead times include the following elements: Queue : This is the fixed wait time in hours before an operation can start. Typically, you would use this as an allowance for printing paperwork (drawings, work instructions), pulling parts from the stock room, issuing parts, and obtaining tooling and jigs. Currently this element is not used. Setup Time : This is a fixed time element for setting up the operation. Run Time : The time is multiplied by the remaining quantity to produce and is used when the work center Basis for Capacity is set to Crew Size . Machine Time : The time is multiplied by the remaining quantity to produce and is used when the work center Basis for Capacity is set to Machines . Move : This is a fixed element after operation completes before it is available at the next operation. The default move time is set in production preferences but it can be changed in production details. Currently this element is not used. The operation times are calculated and converted to days, hours, and minutes as follows: Set Up Hours + ((Qty to Produce * Run Time) / Run Units) Set Up Hours + ((Qty to Produce * Machine Time) / Machine Units) If Run Units or Machine Units are zero, then the hours are zero. The work calendar hours for each work center are then used to calculate the operation start and end dates based solely the number of hours required in each work center. An internal timer is used to determine the relative time at each operation as follows: Capacity is assumed to infinite Crew Size and Number of Machines are not used. Work Center Efficiency is not used Only the total working hours in a work center; that is, if the work hours are 8 am to 5pm with an unpaid break time of 1 hour, then 8 hours are available that day regardless of the time of day. Only the first row from the Work Center Shifts tab is used Example Assume the production order starts on Monday and there are 8 working hours in each work center Monday through Friday. The order has three operations and the total fixed and variable time for each operation is 6 hours. Operation 1 starts on 00:00 relative time on Monday and completes at 06:00 on Monday. Operation 2 starts at 06:00 relative time on Monday and consumes the remaining 2 hours for today and runs from 00:00 to 04:00 relative time on Tuesday. Operation 3 starts at 04:00 relative time on Tuesday and consumes the remaining 4 hours available that day and runs on Wednesday 00:00 to 02:00. If the order started on a Friday and Saturday and Sunday are non-working days, then the Operation would not complete until the next Monday.

Manufacturing Costing The costing of item you make is more complex and detailed than items you buy. You not only have the cost of the materials bought to make an item but also the cost of labor, factory overhead, machinery and/or tooling used in production. And there may be sub-assemblies produced and stored that are input to final assembly of the finished goods items you sell. Manufacturing costings starts with defining the labor rates for each work center, labor cost rates for production employees if labor is to be entered, overhead rates and application methods, rates for machines and tools used in production. These costs are defined in the Bill of Material module which is the foundation for all other manufacturing modules. When you create a bill of material you are also creating the planned or standard cost of the item being produced. Once the bill of material is complete, and the bills for any sub-assemblies needed for the final assembly, a cost roll process on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM508000|AM508000]) Cost Roll (AM508000) form is used to roll up these costs. If the valuation method for the item is Standard , you can update the pending cost of the item and then use the ([~/?ScreenId=IN502000|IN502000]) Update Standard Costs (IN502000) form to apply the new cost. When a production order is created, the cost roll is again used to create the planned production costs. When production transactions are entered, a cost is applied and posted to the work in process account. When production is completed, a costing production receipt is calculated for the value of inventory received. For details, see Costing Production Receipts. Cost Elements Used in Manufacturing Costs are broken down into the following on bills of materials, estimates, and production orders: Materials : The value of the components used to make the stock item. These can be both stock items and non-stock items. For stock items the planned cost is obtained from the Price/Cost tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) form. For production transactions the actual cost is updated when the inventory issue transaction is processed and released. Labor : The value of labor issued or planned to be issued to make the stock item. Planned labor is calculated based on the run units, run time, and work center standard cost. Actual labor is either calculated based on the work center standard cost or the employee cost rate. If labor is backflushed, the time is calculated automatically based on the quantity reported and costed using the work center standard cost. Fixed Labor: if the cost of setup for an operation. Setup is always posted to actual costs when the first quantity is reported for an operation Variable Labor: This is the costs calculated for run units and times Overhead: The value of overhead rates applied to operations and materials. For actual overhead, it is applied only when a quantity is reported for an operation. Fixed Overhead: This represents an amount charged regardless of lot or order size. The the overhead type is Fixed Variable Overhead: This represents overhead calculated on the basis of labor, machines, or quantity. Subcontract: This represent the cost of materials provided to and purchased from a vendor for performing the work. Machine: This is the cost of running a machine for an operation. Tools: This is the cost of tools consumed at an operation.

Outside Processing You may have a need to have some or all of your production processes contracted out to vendors. If could be for a process that you cannot perform in house such as plating or heat treating. You could use a contract manufacturer or subcontractor when your own capacity is not available or if the contractor does repacking operations for you such as creating variety or gifts packs from multiple products. In some industries, contract manufacturing is pretty common: circuit boards; food and beverage; pharmaceuticals, nutraceuticals, and cosmetics; or aerospace and defense. Determining Your Needs These are some of the questions to ponder: Do the contractors hold inventory for you? How will you determine when or if to replenish the inventory at the contractor(s)? Will you be supplying some of the components? By transferring from your inventory? By placing purchase orders with delivery to the contractor? Are services included in the purchase price of the product received by you or are there separate charges for product and labor? What visibility do you need for work being performed by the contractor? For the purposes of this article we will use the term contractor to refer to someone who is performing production work on your behalf and the term vendor when referring to someone you buy from for any materials you supply to the contractor. Of course, the contractor is a vendor also since you are buying services or product from them. Inventory Visibility and Replenishment If you are supplying components, either by transferring from your inventory or by purchasing to the contractor location, you can create a warehouse for contractor or use a warehouse location. Regardless a transfer or purchase receipt will need to be performed to update the on hand balances. If you are sending out items to be processed (such as painting or coating) then you may opt to track them using the production order. Warehouse Location All inventory in warehouse locations is considered as on hand for availability, inventory replenishment, and/or MRP calculations unless excluded. This may not be an issue if component inventory is only held at the contractor. If you create a purchase order to replenish inventory at the contractor you will need to ensure that you specify the correct warehouse location for the purchase receipt when notified. For transfers within a warehouse only one-step transfer types are allowed. There is no tracking of the in transit inventory. This may not be an issue with contractors nearby your location. You can use the standard inventory inquiries and reports to view the inventory by location within a warehouse. Separate Warehouse A separate warehouse may offer greater flexibility in some ways. You can use the inventory one-step transfer but you may also use the inventory two-step transfer if tracking the in transit inventory is desired. Additionally, a separate warehouse allows you to use a Sales Order transfer order type. The transfer order moves through the same processes as sales orders to prepare shipments and shipment paperwork, including carrier labels, and to collect freight/landed costs. With a separate warehouse you can use Inventory Replenishment and/or MRP to maintain any desired inventory levels at the contractor warehouse. You can also decide to exclude this warehouse completely from MRP. Tracking Inventory Using Production Orders If you are purchasing a service to perform an operation on material you supply for each production order (for example, sending out an item to be powder coated) it may suffice to track the status using a production order. You would issue the materials from your inventory to the production order. The production order operation indicates the inventory issued, the ([~/?ScreenId=IN402000|IN402000]) Inventory Allocation Details (IN402000) form would show the inventory issued under the Work in Process column, and the production order holds the materials issued value. Vendor shipments created on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM310000|AM310000]) Vendor Shipments (AM31000) form can be used to transfer the production item and the components you are supplying to the vendor without having to create a separate warehouse or warehouse location. If you do stock items at a vendor warehouse in advance of production then a separate warehouse or stock location is recommended. Stock and Non-Stock Items You would create an inventory item to recognize the cost of an item being produced and returned to you. For example, the contractor is filling containers you have supplied with materials they supply; you will be billed for the cost of the materials in the container and labor applied to create the product. Remember that the cost of vendor supplied materials should reflect the added value and not include the cost of materials you provided; those materials costs are recognized when you issue them to the production order. The inventory item would be used to purchase the service and its receipt would serve as a signal to complete the operation. You can use a stock or non-stock inventory item for the services cost. Stock Item The advantages of using a stock item are the following: Purchase orders for a stock item are allocated to the production order and are changed to stock allocations when received. The ([~/?ScreenId=AM305500|AM305500]) Unreleased Material Allocations (AM305500) form can be used to issue the allocated stock items. Stock item can use any valuation method and may better reflect the purchase cost of the service. Stock items can be planned by MRP. Transport costs can be applied to the unit costs of services received. Non-Stock Inventory Item You can also create a non-stock item to recognize costs for services that are separately billed or when services are the only charge. Non-stock inventory items can only use standard cost valuation. You can use a different non-stock item for each contractor service charge or use the same item for each service charge. If you use the same item set the standard cost equal to 1.00 and use the quantity required column on the bill of materials for the contractor amount. For example, the contractor charges .53 per piece for one item and 1.23 for another; you would set the quantity required to .53 and 1.23 respectively. Non-stock items cannot be allocated to a production order and must be issued or backflushed in order to post the cost at standard cost. You can decide if a purchase order receipt is required for the non-stock item or not. Requiring a receipt allows the matching of the receipt to the vendor bill. Generated Transactions for Non-Stock Items Used for Services If you use non-stock items for materials used in outside processing, and according to business processes of your organization costs of these items must be accrued, you select the Accrue Cost check box on the Price/Cost Information tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) Non-Stock Items (IN202000) form. With this check box selected and when the Require Receipt check box is selected on the General Settings tab of the same form, the system posts costs of materials when receiving the items to the warehouse of your organization and releasing a production order to the Expense Accrual account. Transactions generated on the inventory receipt release are listed in the following table. Account Source of Account Debit Credit Expense Accrual account Item Amount 0.00 PO Accrual account Item 0.00 Amount If the Accrue Cost check box is selected on the Price/Cost Information tab and the Require Receipt check box is cleared on the General Settings tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) Non-Stock Items form for the non-stock item used for outside services, then you create the AP bill with this non-stock item. When you release the AP bill, the transactions listed in the following table are generated. Account Source of Account Debit Credit Expense account Item Amount 0.00 AP account Item 0.00 Amount When you issue or backflush the non-stock item for a production order, transactions listed in the following table are generated. Account Source of Account Debit Credit Work in Process account Item Amount 0.00 Expense Accrual account Item 0.00 Amount If the Accrue Cost check box is cleared on the Price/Cost Information tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) Non-Stock Items form, the amounts are posted to the Expense account instead of the Expense Accrual account. In the previous versions of Acumatica ERP Manufacturing Edition, we recommended that when using non-stock items for materials in outside processing you specify the same account for the Expense Accrual GL account and Expense GL account. This ensured the proper accounting. By using the same account for both the expense and accrual the amounts will offset; the Work in Process account specified in the production order will hold the expense of outside services to include in the product cost. Bills of Material Because you can have more than one bill of material for a stock item, you can have a bill for in-house production and a different bill for the contractor. Work Centers Typically, you would want to post the contractor costs to the production order by issuing the inventory item. With the work center for the contractor(s) you can apply additional costs not covered by the purchase order such as overhead. When creating the work center, you should set the Standard Cost to zero so as not to add labor costs when reporting operation completions. The setup time can be use to indicate a fixed time required for the subcontract operation or if the time varies, use the run time. Backflushing Unless you need to do specific issues of lots or serial numbers, we would recommend backflushing the materials consumed or produced by the contractor. If you are using a stock inventory item for the service cost, process the purchase order receipt before issuing or backflushing the material to update the average or FIFO cost. If you are using a non-stock item and the services cost is different than planned, issue the non-stock item for the quantity needed to reflect the cost. Set Up Outside Process The enhanced outside process features can be used with both bills of material and estimates. DO the following to set up the outside process: On the ([~/?ScreenId=CS201010|CS201010]) Numbering Sequences (CS201010) form, create a numbering sequence] to use for vendor shipments and enter it on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM102000|AM102000]) Production Preferences (AM102000) form. On the same form you can specify settings for processing vendor shipments in the Vendor Shipment Settings section. On the ([~/?ScreenId=AM207000|AM207000]) Work Centers (AM207000) form, create or modify work centers and select the Outside Process check box. The Mass Update button on the Where Used tab can be used to select or clear the Outside Process check box for some or all bills of material operations using the work center. However, it cannot update the material lines. Add stock items or non-stock items you will use to pay the vendor for their services. On the ([~/?ScreenId=AM208000|AM208000]) Bill of Material (AM208000) form, create or modify the bill of material for the item being produced for each material used for the outsource operation as follows: Select the Material Type of Subcontract and enter the appropriate Subcontract Source . Enter the appropriate vendor information on the Outside Process tab of the operation. Specify the warehouse if different from the bill of material warehouse from which you will issue the Ship to Vendor materials. If you have an existing production created before step 2, you can use the ([~/?ScreenId=AM209000|AM209000]) Production Order Details (AM209000) from to setup the outside process operations. Process Flow The process flow is the following: Create a the production order in either of the following forms: ([~/?ScreenId=AM201500|AM201500]) Production Order Maintenance (AM201500) ([~/?ScreenId=AM400000|AM400000]) MRP Display (AM400000) ([~/?ScreenId=SO301000|SO301000]) Sales Orders (SO301000) ([~/?ScreenId=AM510000|AM510000]) Create Production Orders (AM510000) Create the purchase order to pay the vendor for the service. You can use the ([~/?ScreenId=PO505000|PO505000]) Create Purchase Orders (PO505000) form to create one or more purchase orders for one or more production orders, the ([~/?ScreenId=AM401000|AM401000]) Critical Materials (AM401000) form, or the Create PO action on the Outside Process tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=AM209000|AM209000]) Production Order Details (AM209000) form for a single production order and purchase order. Any of these methods create an allocation from the purchase order to the production order. You can view the created purchase by clicking the Allocations button for the material line on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM209000|AM209000]) Production Order Details form. Release the production order by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201500|AM201500]) Production Order Maintenance (AM201500) or ([~/?ScreenId=AM500000|AM500000]) Release Production Orders (AM500000) form. Issue any materials required for the operations you perform prior to the outside process step that are not marked for backflush from the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201500|AM201500]) Production Order Maintenance form or by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM300000|AM300000]) Materials (AM300000) form. Enter any required move or labor transactions you perform in house prior to the outside process step on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM302000|AM302000]) Move (AM302000) or ([~/?ScreenId=AM301000|AM301000]) Labor (AM301000) forms . Enter the vendor shipments on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM310000|AM310000]) Vendor Shipments (AM310000) form. Print the pick list by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM644000|AM644000]) Vendor Shipment Pick List (AM644000) report. Enter any required lot or serial numbers for the production item and materials and confirm the vendor shipment. This will issue the Ship to Vendor materials and update the subcontract actual cost. On the ([~/?ScreenId=AM642000|AM642000]) Vendor Shipment Packing List (AM642000) form, print the pick lists that will accompany the items being sent to vendor. Receive the purchase order used to pay the vendor for the outside service. This will update the subcontract actual cost with the actual purchase cost. Issue any materials needed for the remaining operations Complete the remaining operations for the production order using Move or Labor transactions. Review the production order variances and resolve any discrepancies Close the production order individually or by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM506000|AM506000]) Close Production Orders (AM506000) form. Planning Bills of Material A planning bill of material, sometimes referred to as a Pseudo Bill , is a grouping of operations and materials used in MRP for planning purposes. They are defined on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM208000|AM208000]) Bill of Material (AM208000) form exactly the same way as a production bill. You can choose to designate any bill of material for an item as the planning bill or create a new unique bill. If you do not have a planning bill, then the default bill of material is used for planning. There are no restrictions on using the same bill of material as both the default and planning bill. Why Use a Planning Bill? Planning bills are most often used to help forecast or master schedule products that have many options where the final configuration is not determined until an order is received. Usually, a planning bill flattens out the multiple level bill of material to a single level bill; that is, the subassembly bills are removed and their key components made components of the planning bill. Alternatively, you could create a planning stock item and construct a planning bill with its components the actual items you sell making each component a phantom if you only want to see their components in MRP and not the assembly. A manufacturer of desktop computers may have multiple product lines with hundreds of combination of options for processors, memory, storage, monitors, etc. Some of the options may be available across multiple product lines. In order to compress the order to ship lead time, it is desirable to have the components already in stock. Rather than attempt to forecast each product model for every variant, it more feasible to create a pseudo inventory item that will never be sold and construct a planning bill of material with the component options expressed in quantities represented by their past usage. For example, each desktop computer model can have a 500GB or 1TB capacity disk drive and 60% of the customer select the 1TB disk drive. A planning bill could look like this: Planning Bill of Material for All Desktop Computers Component Quantity Required DiskDrive-1TB .6 DiskDrive-500GB .4 You would create a forecast or MPS for the planning stock item to drive out the requirements to make or purchase the disk drives. Similarly, you would add other components to the planning bills in their percentages. Managing MRP with Planning Bills It's important to consider that both the planning item and stock items are driving down component demand. The planning bill is intended to represent anticipated sales in the future so as to make or buy the necessary components in a timely manner. When you enter the sales orders or production orders for the items to be sold, they will drive component demand also. As customer orders are received, you should reduce the forecast or MPS for the planning item so as not to overstate the component demand. You can use the Planning Horizon setting in MRP Preferences to specify when to ignore forecasts and use just actual demand. For example, you expect customers to typically place orders 2 weeks in advance of anticipated ship dates; therefore, you would set the forecast Planning Horizon or MPS Time Fence to 14 days. You should review the actual component usage and periodically adjust their percentages in the planning bill.

Using Attributes in Manufacturing Attributes created on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS205000|CS205000]) Attributes (CS205000) form are used for multiple purposes in Acumatica ERP. In many cases they eliminate for customizing forms and when attached to a record, for example, a stock item record, they are automatically available for use in inquiries. You can use attributes in manufacturing forms as well. Using Attributes in Bills of Material and Production Orders Attributes can be attached to bills of material header and/or operations and are copied onto the production order when the order is created. Attributes can be specified for each production order type on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201100|AM201100]) Production Order Types (AM201100) form. Attributes can also be added to a production order manually by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201500|AM201500]) Production Order Maintenance (AM201500) form. Attributes created at the BOM level become order level attributes for the production order. If an order level attribute is enabled for data entry it is available when reporting all operations of the production order. For example, you could create a required attribute for a quality control check for all operations or to record a process value. If enabled attribute values can be entered for the production order and operation when you enter a move or labor transaction by using the Production Attribute Entry form. If an attribute is marked as Transaction Required , it must be entered. The attribute values entered during production reporting are specific to the transaction. Using Attributes in Product Configurator Attributes have the following purposes in the product configurator: They can be used to collect data used in formulas to calculate the quantity required for an option. For example, calculating the quantity required based on an attribute value for length. They can be used to capture a value used in production. For example, the text for printing or engraving on a custom piece. They can be used to with rules to include or exclude features and options. Attributes and their values used on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM306000|AM306000]) Configuration Entry (AM306000) form are copied to the production order created as view only.

Work Center Substitution This features provides the ability to have work centers automatically substituted during production order creation based on the warehouse used for production. It can eliminate the need to have warehouse specific bills of material. A company may have multiple production facilities where an item can be made. The components use to make the end item are the same, although they may have different costs, and the production process is the same but the production facilities have different labor and overhead rates. To use this feature, you must have the Multiple Warehouse feature enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. Substituting Work Centers The substitution of work centers is controlled by the Substitute Work Centers check box on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201100|AM201100]) Production Order Types (AM201100) form. Substitutes for each work center are defined on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM207000|AM207000]) Work Centers (AM207000) form. If the order type allows substitute work centers, then during production order creation or change of warehouse, and the order is in a planned status the process will look at the current work centers. If the current work center warehouse used for the production order does not match the warehouse for the production order the substitute logic will try to find a substitute from the work center substitute work centers tab were the warehouse on the substitute tab matches the current production warehouse. When substituted the work center description can replace the operation description based on the setting on the work center. The backflush labor setting and any work center overheads are copied to the production order during this process.

Bills of Material The Bills of Material part of the Acumatica ERP Manufacturing edition is the foundation for all of the other parts of the edition. A bill of material , or product structure, is a list of the production operations required to build a single level assembly or subassembly. Bills of material become hierarchical when a subassembly is used as a component in another assembly or subassembly. The complete structure, from finished goods down through each subassembly down to raw materials, is referred to a multilevel bill of material. For each operation in a bill of material you specify the operation times (queue, setup, labor, machine, and move), the materials or components required, the machines available to use, and any tooling. Each element of a bill of material has an associated cost and these cost elements are rolled up level by level to calculate the total cost of the finished good. The rolled up cost becomes the standard or planned cost to produce an item. In the topics describing bills of material, you create work centers, work calendars, shifts, labor codes, overhead rates, machine, and tools. A work center has a defined capacity which is used by scheduling processes in the Material Requirements Planning and Production Management parts of Manufacturing edition to determine when an operation must be started and when it will be completed and when the materials will need to be issued. This chapter contains all the information you need to configure and use the bills of material in Acumatica ERP.

Bills of Material: General Information The Bills of Material part is the building blocks of the manufacturing software. It is where the operations and work centers are defined, along with materials, steps, overhead, and tools and/or machines. This is where the production order needs can be defined for your inventory items to become that finished good. What this section will cover: We will discuss the key features of the Bills of Material part. Relationship to other Acumatica ERP functional areas Key Features BOM / Routing Maintenance: The BOM / Routing provides the ability to directly update the bills of material and routing information by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM208000|AM208000]) Bill of Material (AM208000) form. Planning Bills of Material: This process facilitates the forecast, or master production schedule, of product families and/or to order assemblies where the specific configuration is not known until you receive the customer order. For details, see Planning Bills of Material. Activity Based Costing: The system provides a means to provide detailed costing well beyond the cost of the raw materials and labor. Tools costs can be consumed based on usage setup through the ([~/?ScreenId=AM205500|AM205500]) Tools (AM205500) form. User-defined overhead costs can be setup through the Overhead Overhead (AM202500) form. These costs can be accrued at a fixed rate, by labor hour and by the quantity completed. The overhead costs can be associated to a specific product (BOM / routing) or they can be tied to a work center. You are not limited to a finite number of overhead IDs. The user can set up as many or as few as they want. Alternate BOM / Routing: Too often in manufacturing systems, the systems will only support a single bill of material for a finished good product. To setup alternate bills of material, you often had to set up multiple inventory items. Manufacturing edition provides you with the ability to set up a single finished good item (or subassembly) and create alternate BOMs and routings for that same product. A good use of this is in a situation where the manufacturer has multiple sites. However, they make the same product at the sites. All too often, the different sites have different machinery, work centers, shifts, costs, etc. The system allows you to set up a specific bill of material / routing for each site. Backflushing: The production transactions can backflush labor and materials and is controlled by the bills of material. By selecting the operations and materials that need to be backflushed this provides the user more control in how and what is being costed. The system will backflush lot- and serial-tracked items based on the usage parameters. By-Products Support: By-products are entered as negative materials on the BOM. These materials will be received into inventory at the cost specified on the BOM or at the standard cost if that is what is being used. By-products can be setup to backflush automatically or can be received by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM300000|AM300000]) Materials (AM300000) or ([~/?ScreenId=AM503000|AM503000]) Release AM Documents (AM503000) forms. Phantoms: Phantom items can be entered on the BOM. They are referred to as phantoms because they show up on the BOM but disappear when a production order is created. Only manufactured items with a BOM can become phantoms. Several advantages to phantoms in the system include the following: Ability to be a true phantom or subassembly Phantoms can be stocked Multilevel phantoms are supported Changes to a phantom such as components or quantities when made at the BOM level are carried through the system Production Steps: Specific steps can be defined at the operation level. Steps are the instructions of what needs to be done for the operation. This allows for full documentation when added with any additional notes of the production process. Revision Tracking: A complete revision history of a BOM can be maintained. Multiple revisions can be saved to the revision history tables which provides the ability for the information from the past production BOM to be referenced instead of the most current revision. Shifts: Multiple shift operations are supported through this application through the ([~/?ScreenId=AM205000|AM205000]) Shifts (AM205000) form. You can create as many shifts as is needed together with the following information: Work centers that are available Number of people or machines Efficiency factors Working times by shift Shift differential Relationship to Other Functional Areas Area Usage Inventory > Manufacturing Creation of a bill of material will fill in the Primary BOM ID box on the Manufacturing tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form. Item Warehouse Details > Manufacturing Creation of a bill of material will fill in the Primary BOM ID box on the Manufacturing tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) form.

Bills of Material FAQ In this topic, you will find answers to the frequently asked questions about bills of material. How do I set up inventory items to be able to use a bill of material? The parent item must be a stock item. Materials, aka components, can be stock or non-stock. What should I use for the BOM ID? The BOM ID can be up to 15 characters. The numbering sequence specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM101000|AM101000]) BOM Preferences (AM101000) form defines the format of the BOM ID. As with all numbering sequences in Acumatica ERP, you may have different sequences by branch. You may choose auto-numbering or manual entry. Some may prefer to use the inventory id as the BOM ID when the inventory ID is less than 15 characters. When importing bills of material, generate a sequence in your import data to reflect the format of the BOM ID and check the Manual Numbering box in the numbering sequence. Prior to 2018R2, also uncheck Track Revision History in BOM Preferences. This way if you find a bill to be incorrect you can simply delete it and reimport using the same BOM ID , otherwise it will assign a new number. With Track Revision History checked, bills of materials are not physically deleted; the end date is set to today instead. For 2018R2, a bill of material revision can be deleted as long as it's not referenced. How many bills of material can an inventory item have? As many as you want but only one can be the default bill of material specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) form for the item–warehouse pair. If you desire to have multiple bills of material for a warehouse because of alternate production methods, you might consider using manual numbering and use a suffix to indicate the alternate. You can also have multiple active revisions for a bill of material. How should I number the operations? You should provide for the insertion of new operations. They are sorted as text and not numbers; such as 00030, 020, 10 not 10, 020, 00030. Tips for creating operation numbers are the following: Do not use leading spaces Typically, a sequence of 010, 020, or 100, 110 or 0010, 0020, 0100 are used. The operation numbers are regenerated when a production order is created from the bill to provide for the insertion of operations for a phantom. The numbering starts with 0010 and increments by 10. Operation numbers may be changed at any time. Where do the unit costs for materials in a bill come from? The ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) form is the source for the cost when you add an inventory item to a bill or production order. The cost used is dependent on the item's valuation method. Unit costs can be manually entered or updated by the cost roll process on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM508000|AM508000]) Cost Roll (AM508000) form. When you add a new material the unit cost defaults from the settings of the item–warehouse pair according to the item's valuation method as follows: Average or FIFO: Average cost If the average cost is zero, then the last cost is used. Standard: Standard cost Specific: Last cost For existing materials, the cost roll process can be used to update the unit costs if desired. When production orders are created, the cost roll process obtains the current cost for materials. How does the Cost Roll Process Calculate Costs? Labor for Each Operation ((Setup time / lot size) + Run time converted to hours per piece) * (Work Center Standard Cost) Materials If Batch Size is zero (0) then Qty Required * (1 + Scrap Factor ) If Batch Size is not zero (0) then Qty Required * (1 + Scrap Factor ) * ( Lot Size / Batch Size ) The system copies Lot Size from the Manufacturing tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) form. If the lot size is zero then Min Order Qty is used. If both are zero then a lot size of 1 is used. In all cases, the quantity will be rounded up if the Quantity Round Up is selected on the Manufacturing tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form. Additional details can be found in How Batch Sizes and Quantity Round Up are Used. Machine for Each Operation (Machine hours converted to hours per piece) * (machine standard cost) Tools for Each Operation Quantity required * Unit Cost Overhead Overhead is calculated dependent on the overhead type.

Updating Standard Costs The cost roll process, performed by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM508000|AM508000]) Cost Roll (AM508000) form, is used to update the cost of assemblies. When assemblies use the Standard inventory valuation method, after the process completes, you can use the process to update the pending cost for all or selected assemblies. Before performing the cost roll process, you should review the pending or standard cost of any purchased items with the Standard valuation method that are used in bills of material. Typically, standard costs are updated on an annual basis but they can be updated at any time. In this topic, you will read about processes related to updating standard costs of items used in bills of material. Updating Pending Standard Costs of Purchased Components Before you roll up the costs of assemblies, you need to update the costs of components used in their bills of material. The is no automated process to do this but you can create a Generic Inquiry to export the purchase order history to analyze and calculate a new cost that could be imported to update the pending costs. The Using Manufacturing Data in Inquiries and Reports topic lists the DACs or tables used by the manufacturing forms if you just want to select only items used in a bill. You can also update the pending cost for a item using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form. Previewing Cost Changes If you wish to review the component cost changes, before updating their standard costs, run the ([~/?ScreenId=IN617500|IN617500]) Standard Cost Change Preview (IN617500) report. Rolling Up the Assembly Costs You use the ([~/?ScreenId=AM508000|AM508000]) Cost Roll (AM508000) form with level set to Multi . You make sure to check the appropriate options to Include Fixed Costs and Include Material Scrap Factors if they are used. When the cost roll is completed, on the form toolbar, click Update Pending to update the pending costs for all assemblies. You can select the Use Pending Standard for Purchased Items check box if you have not yet update your standard cost for components. This will use the component pending costs instead of their standard costs. You can perform the cost roll and update pending multiple times. Updating Standard Costs The process of updating standard costs for inventory items, which is run on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN502000|IN502000]) Update Standard Costs (IN502000), moves the pending cost to the standard cost and zeros out the pending cost. The process creates an adjustment batch on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN303000|IN303000]) Adjustments (IN303000) form to update the Inventory and Standard Cost Revaluation GL accounts. Inventory is always revalued when you run the update standard costs process. However, you might want to revalue inventory without updating the current costs of the items to the next pending cost. In this case, on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN502000|IN502000]) Update Standard Costs form, you can select the Revalue Inventory check box. With the check box selected, the form shows all the standard items that have cost layers at the warehouse selected in the Warehouse box. If you run the update process, inventory will be revalued with the current cost, but the current cost will not be updated with the pending cost for the processed items.

Bill of Material: Implementation Checklist Before you start creating and using bills of material (BOM) in the system, you specify bill of material settings to fit your business needs, as described in this topic. You can at any time adjust the settings as your business grows and changes. Before you begin configuring the system, make sure that you have read information in Bills of Material FAQ. Bill of Material Configuration Checklist No. Task Description 1 Define the numbering sequences for bills of material and engineering change control Create a numbering sequence for the bill of material ID (BOM ID) on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS201010|CS201010]) Numbering Sequences (CS201010) form. Specify the sequence on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM101000|AM101000]) BOM Preferences (AM101000) form. Decide if automatic or manual numbering will be used and if you will use different sequences for each branch. If the functionality of engineering change control (ECC) is used, also create the numbering sequences for engineering change requests (ECR) and engineering change orders (ECO). 2 Specify the default revision identifier You specify the identifier of the default revision in the Default Revision box of the ([~/?ScreenId=AM101000|AM101000]) BOM Preferences form. The identifier can be any alphanumeric string but a unique numbering or text should be used to define new revisions. For more information, see Bill of Material Revisions. 3 Determine if duplicate materials will be allowed in the BOM and its operations In the Duplicates on BOM and Duplicates on Operation boxes of the ([~/?ScreenId=AM101000|AM101000]) BOM Preferences form, select one of the following values: Allow Warn Not Allow 4 Define a work calendar Use the ([~/?ScreenId=CS209000|CS209000]) Work Calendar (CS209000) form to define the available hours for the manufacturing floor. 5 Define shifts Use the ([~/?ScreenId=AM205000|AM205000]) Shifts (AM205000) form to define the shifts and their differentials compared to base pay. Some shifts can work at different rates such as overtime or holiday pay. At least one shift is required for each work center. 6 Define labor codes Use the ([~/?ScreenId=AM206500|AM206500]) Labor Codes (AM206500) form to define the labor codes needed for costing and optionally labor entry. You must at least define a labor code with the Direct type. 7 Define work centers Use the ([~/?ScreenId=AM207000|AM207000]) Work Centers (AM207000) form to define the areas where work will be performed. Normally these are areas of a warehouse intended to be used in the production processing such as assembly, cutting, painting, and testing. These can also be used to track outside processing. These track standard labor rates (optional), overheads (optional) and machines (optional). At least one work center is required. 8 Determine labor posting methods Decide if you intend to post labor by backflush or by having your employees report their time against production orders. Backflush of labor posts the planned operation time at the work center standard rate to a production order automatically when an operation/work center has been passed in sequence or completed. Actual time is reported in production management by the ([~/?ScreenId=AM301000|AM301000]) Labor (AM301000) form using either the employee rate or work center rate. Both methods can be used. For more information, see Backflushing Concepts and Labor Reporting. 9 Determine other BOM cost drivers These are different ways that add planned cost to a bill of material and inevitably, actual cost to a production order. These costs are posted when a quantity is reported or backflushed at a production order operation. ([~/?ScreenId=AM202500|AM202500]) Overhead (AM202500): Fixed or multiple variable options allowed ([~/?ScreenId=AM205500|AM205500]) Tools (AM205500): Track the number of uses and cost per piece ([~/?ScreenId=AM204500|AM204500]) Machines (AM204500): Track down time and efficiency 10 Determine material issue methods Decide if you will report material issues to production orders by backflush or actual material pick quantities. Backflush of material issues the planned quantity at the actual of the stock or non-stock items to the production orders automatically when an operation/work center has been passed in sequence or completed. Actual material is reported via production management on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM300000|AM300000]) Materials (AM300000) form. Both methods can be used. For more information, see Backflushing Concepts. 11 Determine manufacturing warehouses Make sure that warehouses needed to produce, issue and receive stock items are defined on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses (IN204000) form. 12 Determine inventory items to be manufactured or purchased. Manufactured or purchased items will need to be defined on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form. In the Source column of the Replenishment Info tab, select Manufacturing for items that will be defined as a BOM. For items that must be purchased, Purchase or Transfer must be selected in this column. 13 Determine if scrap will be required for material requirements calculations A scrap factor can be defined on materials that will increase the amount of material needed to fulfill the quantity required. This is defined in decimal form and is a percentage increase in required amount. 1 represents 100%, .5 equals 50% and, 0 is 0%. Create reason codes on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS211000|CS211000]) Reason Codes (CS211000) form if scrap will be written-off or quarantined. For more information, see Handling Production Scrap and Waste. 14 Determine the lot size for manufactured stock items Use the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items or ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) form to specify the lot size. The lot size is used to allocate fixed cost elements, such as setup and fixed overhead during cost update.

To Create a Work Center Before you can create bills of material you have to create your work centers by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM207000|AM207000]) Work Centers (AM207000) form. Prerequisites Create your calendars by using the ([~/?ScreenId=CS209000|CS209000]) Work Calendar (CS209000) form. Create your shifts by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM205000|AM205000]) Shifts (AM205000) form. Create your labor codes by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM206500|AM206500]) Labor Codes (AM206500) form. If overhead is to be used, create your overhead rates by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM202500|AM202500]) Overhead (AM202500) form. If machine are to be scheduled and/or used for costing, create your machines by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM204500|AM204500]) Machines (AM204500) form. To Create a Work Center Open the ([~/?ScreenId=AM207000|AM207000]) Work Centers (AM207000) form. Enter the Work Center ID , Description , and Warehouse . Enter the Standard Cost used to calculate the planned labor. Select the Basic for Capacity which is used for scheduling production operations and the Scrap Action Default . The Backflush Materials and Backflush Labor are defaults when adding new operations and materials to a bill of material. On the Shift Info tab, enter a Shift ID to define the capacity of this work center and is used to report employee labor. For each Shift ID , enter the following: A Calendar that defines the working hours of the work center. A Labor Code that defines the labor offset account when labor is entered or backflushed. Enter any additional shifts as required. Optionally enter overhead factors on the Overhead tab. Optionally enter machines used by this work center on the Machines tab. On the form toolbar, click Save .
