To Create Bills of Material You create bills of materialsby using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM208000|AM208000]) Bill of Material (AM208000) form. Prerequisites Create your work centers by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM207000|AM207000]) Work Centers (AM207000) form. To Create a Bill of Material Open the ([~/?ScreenId=AM208000|AM208000]) Bill of Material (AM208000) form. If the numbering sequence for BOM ID on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM101000|AM101000]) BOM Preferences (AM10100) form is set to Manual Numbering enter the BOM ID . Enter the Revision for this bill of material. The default is from ([~/?ScreenId=AM101000|AM101000]) BOM Preferences (AM10100) . Enter the Inventory ID of the stock item and Warehouse ; a bill of materials is unique to an inventory item and warehouse. Change or accept the current business date as the Start Date on or after this bill of material becomes effective. Optionally enter the End Date when this bill of material no longer is effective. Optionally enter a Description for this bill of material. Click the Add Row button to add an operation. For each operation enter: The Operation ID which is the order in which operations will be processed. The numbering should allow for insertion of operations between existing operations. Enter the Work Center where the operation will be performed. Accept or change the Oper Desc that defaults from the Work Center description. Accept or change the Setup Time . Enter the Run Units which is the number of items produced in the Run Time . Enter the Run Time as the amount of labor required to produce the Run Units . The unit and time are used with the work center standard cost to calculate the planned labor cost. If the Work Center Basis for Capacity is Machines , enter the Machine Units and Machine Time . The units and time are used with the machine standard cost to calculate the machine cost element. Accept or change the Backflush Labor and Scrap Action that default from the Work Center . Once you have entered an operation you can enter the details or continue to add all of the operations and then enter the details. The details for each operation are the Materials , Steps , Tools , and Overheads . Enter the materials as follows: Enter the Inventory ID of the stock or non-stock inventory item needed for the operation. Accept or change the Description that defaults from the inventory item description. Accept or change the Qty Required to make one unit of the parent item, Accept or change the UOM that defaults from the inventory item base UOM. Accept or change the Unit Cost that defaults from the Item Warehouse record. The unit cost if informational only and when you cost a bill of material the current Item Warehouse cost is always used. Accept or change the Backflush setting that defaults from the operation Work Center . Enter the Warehouse only if the material will be issued from a different warehouse than the parent warehouse. Enter a Location only if the material will only be issued from a fixed location. Add a new row to add additionally materials for the operation. Optionally enter a Scrap Factor to scale up the material quantity required. 0.05 is 5 percent. Optionally enter the Steps to provide additional instructions for the operation. Optionally enter any Tools required for this operation. The toll Qty Required and Unit Cost are used to calculate the tools cost element. Tools can also be scheduled. Optionally enter any Overhead rates that are specific for this bill of material; typically overhead is set for the Work Center . If this bill of material can be used immediately, clear the Hold box. On the form toolbar, click Save .

row.Content: The Material Requirements Planning (MRP) part of the Manufacturing suite integrates with Inventory, Sales Orders, Purchase Orders, Bills of Material, and Production Management.
row.PlainText: Material Requirements Planning The Material Requirements Planning (MRP) part of the Manufacturing suite integrates with Inventory, Sales Orders, Purchase Orders, Bills of Material, and Production Management.

row.column: Material Requirements Planning: General Information The art of balancing supply and demand is critical to any manufacturing organization. Forms of the Material Requirements Planning (MRP) part provide powerful planning tools that enables your organization to satisfy customer requirements, while maintaining optimal inventory levels. Material Requirements Planning In the part: Sales activities, Master Production Schedules (MPS), and forecasts can be viewed in one centralized location Flexible selection criteria for creation of purchase and/or production orders Provides recommendations to manage changes to firm production and/or purchase orders What this topic will cover: We will discuss the key features of MRP We will review the core MRP process and how it works and what it does Relationship to other Acumatica ERP modules Key Features Full Regeneration (FRG) A FRG can be scheduled to run in the middle of the night when most of the office personnel are not in the office. The FRG wipes out all the existing MRP data and pulls all the data in from across the system. It then replans what materials are required either to be produced or purchased. In Acumatica ERP, you can set up automated processing for most processing forms instead of initiating the processing manually. For details, see Scheduled Processing. Suggested Replenishment Orders MRP generates planned orders to balance demand with supply. From MRP you convert the planned orders into actual purchase, transfer, and production orders. Relationship to Other Functional Areas Area Usage Inventory > Replenishment Classes You can create a replenishment class with the replenishment source of Manufacturing on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN208800|IN208800]) Replenishment Classes (IN208800) form. Inventory > Replenishment Seasonality The factors used for the seasonality periods can be applied to forecasts by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM502000|AM502000]) Generate Forecast (AM502000) form. Inventory > Replenishment Parameters Values for safety stock, added lead time, reorder point, and maximum quantity specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) and ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) forms are used to calculate the suggested purchase and production orders. Inventory > Warehouses You can specify for each warehouse the demand and supply options. For example, in forecasts, if all are cleared, as would be the case for a warehouse used for returns or defective material, then items in the warehouse will not be planned. Sales Orders The promise date of open sales order lines for stock items is used as the demand date. Optionally you can include or exclude sales orders on hold or on credit hold. Purchase Orders The promise date of open purchase order lines with the Goods for Inventory type is used as the supply date. Optionally you can include or exclude purchase orders on hold. Bills of Material The effective date start and end dates of active ([~/?ScreenId=AM208000|AM208000]) Bill of Material (AM208000) determine which one is used to schedule suggested production orders and their material requirements based on the calculated start or end dates. The operation times or fixed lead times are used to forward or backward schedule the suggested production orders. The effective and expiration dates of each material determine if a material is active on the start date. Production Orders The start date of a production order created by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201500|AM201500]) Production Order Maintenance (AM201500) form is the date required for each material; the end date is the supply date for the item being manufactured. Optionally you can include or exclude production orders on hold.

MRP FAQ This topic addresses the common question about the Material Requirements Planning processes. When should MRP be run? Generally, MRP should be run before each business day after all sales and purchase orders have been entered and after all transaction affecting inventory have been posted. Since this is a very resource dependent process, it should be run so as not to conflict with database maintenance processes. What is the Difference between the MRP Display and the MRP Exceptions ? On the ([~/?ScreenId=AM400000|AM400000]) MRP Display (AM400000) form, a list of suggested supply orders (aka planned orders) that need to be converted to actual purchase, production, or transfer orders is displayed. The primary use of MRP exceptions, displayed on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM403000|AM403000]) MRP Exceptions (AM403000) form, is to execute the recommended actions on existing actual supply orders to meet requirements. This includes the following: Expediting or de-exediting existing purchase and production orders to meet demand; Canceling supply orders that are no longer needed; Transferring inventory from one warehouse to another to meet demand; Reviewing sales, purchase, and production orders that on hold and thus ignored by MRP; As a list of late purchase and production orders. It is commonly the first thing a planner or buyer will look at, particularly for expedites, before looking at the new planned orders. Which Items are planned? All stock items with the MRP Item box selected on the Manufacturing tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form. MRP plans at the item–warehouse level; that is, only supply and demand for the stock item and warehouse combination are used. However, if there is a demand for an item and warehouse and there is supply in another warehouse, an MRP exception of the Transfer Available type is generated on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM403000|AM403000]) MRP Exceptions (AM403000) form. Stock items with the status of Inactive or Marked for Deletion are never planned. How does MRP determine which components are used? For production orders, the materials details with a quantity remaining are always used. For planned orders the default planning bill and its most recent active revision are used; if a planning bill is not specified, then the default bill is used. For MPS orders, the bill specified on the MPS order is used. Additionally, the Effective Start Date and Effective End Date specified for each material line in the specified parent bill of material is used to determine if a component is effective on the planned order or planned operation start date. For 2019R1, the active bill of material selected is based on the effective dates of the bill revision. For example, if a revision exists for a future start date it will be used for planned orders with a start date on or after this date. It is possible also to have a bill of material effective between a range of dates. In what sequence does MRP plan? MRP plans top down; it uses the bill of material low level code to determine what items to plan first. The first items planned have a low level code of zero. If a planned order is generated for a manufactured item, then a requirement is inserted for each of the stock items components as specified in its default bill of material on the Manufacturing of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) form. If there is no planning bill of material specified, then the default bill of material is used. The process continues down through the low level codes doing the same gross to net calculations at each level. What dates does MRP use for supply and demand orders? Sales order line Ship On date (including transfers). The sales order defaults this as the Requested On date minus the lead days for this customer (delivery settings). Purchase order line Promised date Production order End Date for supply Production order Start Date or operation Start Date for the materials required. The same logic is used for MPS and MRP planned orders. What data does MRP use and what data can be excluded? Forecasts Sales Orders, including open transfer orders Shipments not released Inventory On Hand MPS Orders Production Orders Purchase Orders By specifying preferences on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM100000|AM100000]) MRP Preferences (AM100000) form, you can decide if sales order on hold, purchase orders on hold, and/or production orders on hold are included or not. An Exception Message is generated for each order on hold and should be reviewed after running MRP. You can clear the check boxes above on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses (IN204000) form to exclude selected data. If all are cleared, the warehouse is excluded completely. How do allocations impact MRP? The current process of regenerating MRP uses all the allocation details records, as shown on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN402000|IN402000]) Inventory Allocation Details (IN402000) form. It does not matter if the allocation records are included in supply or deducted from demand on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201500|IN201500]) Availability Calculation Rules (IN201500) because MRP needs to see all supply and demand. There are exceptions: The settings specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM100000|AM100000]) MRP Preferences (AM100000) form for Include Orders on Hold are used. Supply and demand for production orders with a status of Completed are ignored. Inactive stock items are excluded from planning. How is inventory on hand calculated? For each warehouse, it is the on hand balance of any warehouse location where the MRP box is selected. If the MRP box is cleared for a warehouse location, then any production orders with this location as the planned receipt location are also excluded from MRP. Are non-stock items planned? No, they are not inventoried. How does MRP determine if an item is manufactured or purchased? The source of an item is specified in the Replenishment Source box on the Manufacturing tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) form. How Should Purchased Items be Set Up? MRP uses settings specified either on the Replenishment Info tab or on the Manufacturing tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form depending of whether the Inventory Replenishment feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000): If the feature is enabled, then settings specified on the Replenishment Info tab are used. You can override replenishment settings specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Itemsform with the settings specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) form. The following settings are used: Safety Stock or Reorder Point : The value used is determined by the value of Stocking Method on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM100000|AM100000]) MRP Preferences (AM100000) form. If you have multiple warehouses, you should only set these values on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details form. The vendor details for the default vendor from the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items form, unless overridden on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details form, are used as follows: Add Lead Time (Days) : This is used to adjust the default vendor lead time Min. Order Qty : This becomes the minimum order quantity for the planned orders. Lot Size : The planned orders are rounded up to the nearest multiple of lot size. If demand is 37 and the min is 20 and the lot size is 5, then the planned order quantity will be 40. Max. Order Qty : The planned order quantity cannot be greater than the maximum. Multiple planned orders will be created to cover the demand. If an item does not have a default vendor, then the values are taken from the Manufacturing tab. How are forecasts used? A forecast, created by using the Forecast Forecast (AM202000) form, is due on their start date. If the start date is earlier than the business date plus the Planning Horizon specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM100000|AM100000]) MRP Preferences (AM100000) form, the forecast record is updated to clear the Active box on the forecast record. If the forecast has the Dependent box selected, then sales orders with a promise date between the Begin Date and End Date of every forecast are automatically reduced by the sales order line open quantity. For example, if the forecast is 200 for 9/1 to 9/30, then all sales orders with a promise dates between 9/1 and 9/30 have a total open quantity of 150, the remaining forecast of 50 is used. Are forecasts customer specific? Yes, you can reference a customer on a forecast and that forecast is only consumed by only sales orders for that customer. You should not mix both customer specific and non-specific forecasts for an inventory item because sales orders for that customer will net against both. You could however increase the non-specific forecast to include the customer specific forecast. How are grace days used? For each demand date, MRP determines if a supply order within the grace days can fully satisfy the demand. The grace days are specified in the Grace Period box on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM100000|AM100000]) MRP Preferences (AM100000) form. If the demand is no fully satisfied by supply orders with the grace days, then a planned order is created to satisfy the remaining demand. The following table shown an example of using the grace period. Date Demand (-) or Supply (+) Qty Projected On Hand October 6th -10 Production Material -10 October 10th -10 Production Material -20 November 9th 40 Purchase Order 20 In the above example, if the Grace Period is 30 calendar days, then the purchase order supply due on November 9th only satisfies the demand of October 10th and a planned order will be created to satisfy the demand of October 6th. If the Grace Period is 90 days, then both demands are fully satisfied by the Purchase Order supply and no planned order is created. The logic does not apply when a supply order due date is earlier than the demand date and it satisfies all demands because there is no need to create a planned order. You should consider your demand and supply patterns, supply lead times, and minimum order quantities to determine an appropriate value for Grace Period . Regardless of the Grace Period setting, exceptions messages are always generated to expedite or defer supply orders. The generation of exception messages is controlled by the MRP preferences for Days Before and Days After . What are suggested values for Days Before and Days After? First, both values must be less than or equal to the Grace Days . The greater the values, less exception messages are generated, however reviewing the exception messages helps to ensure that supply orders are will be received in time. You should consider your lead times and if your suppliers, either your own manufacturing or your vendors, can adapt to your new due dates. You have to consider also the number of times you have to ask your suppliers to change their promise dates. Selection of a demand require date Days Before : If most of your lead times are a week or less, then 7 days would be appropriate. You would want your vendor to defer a delivery when demand changes to a later date. If your lead times are larger, then you need to consider how often you want to ask your vendors to adjust their promise dates. Days After : This is the more critical value since a late delivery from a supplier impacts your ability to manufacture and/or ship to customers. A value of 2 to 5 days is suggested. How Can I Consolidate Planned Orders? The Group Planning number of days provides you with ability to specify how planned orders are grouped for consolidation when you select them on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM400000|AM400000]) MRP Display (AM400000) form. The first planned order selected is the starting date and is assigned a Group Nbr of 1. Then any planned orders with a required date with the group planning days are assigned the to group 1. The next planned order, for the same item, or planned order for a new item are assigned Group Nbr of 2.

MRP Processor Step Description Initialization The first step the FRG performs is an Initialization phase. Certain variables are initialized. A connection is made to the database. Parameters are read from the MRP Setup. Set Low Level Codes The first step is to set the low level codes of all the Inventory Items. This allows MRP to process the highest level items that may generate demand for the lower items. First Pass First Pass is the information-gathering phase. The MRP Processor will go out and bring together all the various supplies and demands for inventory. First Pass first gathers current inventory values, what the current quantity on hand is. The safety stock is removed from this value; MRP treats safety stock as if those quantities were not available. First Pass then determines where it will get future supplies. This may be Finished Good Items on Open Production Orders or it may Open Purchase Orders. It will then look at demands from Sales Orders, Shippers, and Material Requirements on Purchase Orders. First Pass will process the Master Planning Schedule (MPS). It first updates the MPS information. Those MPS records that fall outside of the MPS Time Fence are marked as inactive. In addition, existing Production Orders may consume the MPS. The Production Order can consume the MPS even though that Production Order is completed and closed. A Production Order will consume the MPS based on the scheduled End Date of the Production Order. Forecasts Forecasts are processed as each level is processed. Therefore, if the Forecast is dependent, ALL requirements may consume the Forecast. This allows the user to not only Forecast at the Sales Order level, but also Forecast at Lower Levels. Adjust Quantities The next step is to reconcile existing supplies with existing demands at each level. If we have a sales order for 100 units and a production order that is making 100 units in time, then MRP does not have to plan anything for that sales order. The key to this routine is that to remember MRP is extremely date sensitive. In other words, in the above example, if that production order was not going to make those units for another 60 days then MRP does need to plan something else for that sales order so that it ships in time. MRP uses the Grace Period on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM100000|AM100000]) MRP Preferences (AM100000) form to determine if that supply can be used for the current demand. Blowdown Once all the existing data is reconciled, the Blowdown routine will now plan MRP orders. This routine is looking at all demand items that are not being supplied in time for the level being processed. These are being planned out. If a Reorder Qty is set for an Inventory Item, MRP will plan its orders in multiples of that reorder quantity. If the item is a manufactured item, MRP will explode through its Bill of Material and create more requirements for its materials that will be processed at a lower level. The key to this phase is to plan accurate Action dates. The system will calculate Cumulative Lead Times so that if a Sales Order needs to ship on March 22nd, that means the Production Order must be created on March 10th. This also means that the Purchase Order for the raw material that we do not have needs to be placed by March 5th. During this phase, MRP is writing all of its requirements to the MRP details table. The details are reviewed by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM400000|AM400000]) MRP Display (AM400000) and ([~/?ScreenId=AM403000|AM403000]) MRP Exceptions (AM403000) forms. Completion Finally, once all of the requirements are planned, all the data is brought together into the MRP plan table. This table is used so you can view all of the requirements for an item using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM404000|AM404000]) Detail Inquiry (AM404000) form The first section provides brief description of an idea to be detailed in the topic. Usually 3-5 phrases, the last paragraph should clearly list what details are described in the sections of the topic.

Master Schedule vs. Forecast Both create demand and are planned by MRP. Both are exploded down through their bills of material to create dependent demand for their components. How are they different? The key difference is the source. A forecast predicts future demand (orders) that will be placed by customers. A Forecast is a demand item and sales orders typically consume the forecast. The Master Production Schedule (MPS) is a proposed build schedule. It is a planned production schedule that identifies what is being planned to be built in the coming weeks. An MPS can be consumed like a forecast, however an MPS is a planned supply item and it is consumed by a Production Order, a supply item. When do you use a MPS instead of a Forecast? The answer is whose forecast is it? If it is coming from sales identifying what they expect to ship, use Forecasts. If Production is stating that this is what they need to produce, use the MPS. Both forecasts and master production schedules are used to build inventory in anticipation of customer orders and drive down through the bills of materials to create dependent demand for the materials required to build the products. Forecasts or master schedules are especially important when the cumulative lead times from raw materials to finished products are longer than your customers are willing to wait. Even in a make to order environment there may be long lead components that must be sourced and stocked in order to meet customer expectation of delivery. Forecasted demand may be highly seasonal whereas a master production is typically constructed to smooth production; e.g. build stock when demand is low to cover higher demand in future periods. A master production schedule is a statement of production that should take into consideration forecasts, sales order backlog, desired inventory levels, storage constraints, and production resources. Creating Forecasts Forecasts can be generated from historical data by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM502000|AM502000]) Generate Forecast (AM502000) form or manually entered or adjusted using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM202000|AM202000]) Forecast (AM202000) form. When marked as dependent, sales orders reduce or consume the forecast. Creating a Master Production Schedule You can think of MPS orders as firm planned orders and they are treated the same as production orders in MRP; that is, MRP will generate a defer, expedite, or cancel exception when MPS orders are not in synch with demand. MPS orders are entered using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201000|AM201000]) Master Production Schedule (AM201000) form. You can create a Production Order from an MPS Order and similar to forecasts, when marked as dependent, creating a production order reduces or consume an MPS Order. Safety Stocks and Reorder Points Forecasts are inevitably incorrect because of the nature of customer orders. Build schedules may not be executed as planned because of supply or production disruptions. Safety stocks and/or reorder points can be used to buffer demand and supply variability. The ([~/?ScreenId=IN508500|IN508500]) Calculate Replenishment Parameters (IN508500) form can be used to calculate safety stocks and reorder point based on the desired service level, seasonality model, and demand forecast model. Generally, you would set a safety stock or reorder point for the finished goods and not at the component level; an exception would be components used as spare or service items. The added safety stock or reorder point for the finished goods drives down into component demand during MRP regeneration on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM505000|AM505000]) Regenerate MRP (AM505000) form. You should take into consideration demand that triggers MRP replenishment is due on the date the projected on hand balance drops below the safety stock or reorder point and this may not provide sufficient lead time. Additionally, unlike forecasts safety stocks or reorder points are not consumed by sales orders. When possible, a forecast or MPS is a better solution since both represent future demand.

You can at any time adjust the settings as your business grows and changes. No. Task Description 1 Determine the forecast numbering sequence Use the ([~/?ScreenId=CS201010|CS201010]) Numbering Sequences (CS201010) form to define the numbering sequences for forecasts. 2 Determine the MPS type numbering sequences Use the ([~/?ScreenId=CS201010|CS201010]) Numbering Sequences (CS201010) form to define the numbering sequences for MPS types. 3 Determine days before/days after window This is an allowable time frame of a supply item fulfilling a demand item within MRP without producing exception messages. Supply items are events that bring inventory into a warehouse, that is a purchase order or production order. A demand item is an event that takes inventory from a warehouse, that is a sales order or a forecast. A supply item's required date that occurs within this range for a demand item action date should not present exception messages and are considered a valid supply item to fulfill a demand item. Supply items that fall outside of this range may generate a MRP exception message. 4 Specify the planned order type (6.xx and later only) An order type with a function of planned is required. You defined order types by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201100|AM201100]) Production Order Types (AM201100) form. 5 Specify the grace period This is the amount in days after a supply item's promise date it can be used to satisfy demands. Any supply item that does not fall within this range ( Demand Action Date to Demand Action Date plus Grace Period in Days ) will be considered invalid and the MRP tickler screen will plan another supply item to fulfill the demand item. 6 Select the stocking method This determines the value MRP uses to trigger replenishment if the projected quantity available falls below this value either the safety stock or reorder point. 7 Specify the purchase calendar Use the ([~/?ScreenId=CS209000|CS209000]) Work Calendar (CS209000) form to define the calendar MRP uses to calculate action and promise dates from vendor lead times. 8 Determine the planning horizon MRP will plan only those forecasts that are planned to start beyond this amount of days after today. Sales orders, purchase orders, and/or production orders on hold, or for sales orders on credit hold, should be included for the calculation of necessary demand and supply for items in the system. If they are not included, then an MRP exception is generated for each order on hold on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM403000|AM403000]) MRP Exceptions (AM403000) form. 12 Determine if fixed or variable lead times will be used to calculate planned manufacturing order dates. If variable, the operation time elements are planned quantity are used but it will add extra time to the MRP Regeneration process. An item's fixed Manufacturing Lead Time is defined either on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) or ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) form. By default, all items are included for MRP, clear check boxes for any of those that you wish to not plan. 14 Determine warehouses to include in MRP Navigate to ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses (IN204000) form, Manufacturing tab. By default, all features are included for MRP, clear check boxes for any of those that you wish to not plan. By default, all locations are included for MRP, clear check boxes for any of those that you wish to exclude. For example, defective stock or returns waiting disposition. 16 Create replenishment classes If the Inventory Replenishment feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form, use the ([~/?ScreenId=IN208800|IN208800]) Replenishment Classes (IN208800) form to define replenishment classes with sources of Purchased , Manufacturing , and Transfer . The replenishment classes are assigned to stock items and to warehouse stock items. 17 Specify replenishment settings for stock items Define the replenishment settings on the Replenishment Info tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items form. Use the Manufacturing tab to define the settings for Minimum and Maximum order quantities. 19 Determine MPS dependencies MPS can be dependent of actual production orders or not. If they are dependent, the MPS quantity is reduced by creating a production order. 20 Determine forecast dependencies A forecast can be independent or consumed by sales orders. 21 Determine MRP schedule run times Determine the days and time that MRP can be scheduled to run. This is managed on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM205020|SM205020]) Automation Schedules (SM205020) form.

We highly recommend setting up an automation schedule to run MRP regeneration daily during the evening or early morning so the results will be available for the planners and buyers are the start of their work day. You should set it to run after all other scheduled processes that impact supply and demand are run to ensure the MRP process has the most up to date data. Examples of automated processes that affect MRP are the following:[anchor|#_88760bf4-24df-40c5-ae2a-13c00bf26b2b] *Any process that changes the on hand balance of inventory items such as counts, adjustments, purchase receipts, sales order shipments, production reporting, etc. *Any process that creates demand or supply orders or updates these orders to change quantities or dates such as importing sales orders. *Inventory Replenishment processes that calculate safety stock and/or reorder points. *Release of batches or documents that were held during the day such as invoices.
You can create an automation schedule either on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_50_50_00|Regenerate MRP] ([~/?ScreenId=AM505000|AM505000]) or [HelpRoot_FormReference\SM_20_50_20|Automation Schedules] ([~/?ScreenId=SM205020|SM205020]) form.

Scheduling MRP Regeneration We highly recommend setting up an automation schedule to run MRP regeneration daily during the evening or early morning so the results will be available for the planners and buyers are the start of their work day. You should set it to run after all other scheduled processes that impact supply and demand are run to ensure the MRP process has the most up to date data. Examples of automated processes that affect MRP are the following: Any process that changes the on hand balance of inventory items such as counts, adjustments, purchase receipts, sales order shipments, production reporting, etc. Any process that creates demand or supply orders or updates these orders to change quantities or dates such as importing sales orders. Inventory Replenishment processes that calculate safety stock and/or reorder points. Release of batches or documents that were held during the day such as invoices. You can create an automation schedule either on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM505000|AM505000]) Regenerate MRP (AM505000) or ([~/?ScreenId=SM205020|SM205020]) Automation Schedules (SM205020) form.

The Production Management part of the Manufacturing edition, provides you with easy entry of production orders, quick release of planned production orders, availability of using alternate BOMs and routing using revisions, an event history, and easy release of materials.{br}
This chapter contains all the information you need to configure and use production management functionality.
row.PlainText: Production Management The Production Management part of the Manufacturing edition, provides you with easy entry of production orders, quick release of planned production orders, availability of using alternate BOMs and routing using revisions, an event history, and easy release of materials. This chapter contains all the information you need to configure and use production management functionality.

row.column:
The production management functionality is used to control and track the transformation of raw materials and component parts into finished items and sub-assemblies. It is the execution module in the manufacturing suite.{br}
The primary features of production management are described briefly in this topic. ==Easy Entry of the Production Order== Production orders can be created by using forms related to material requirements planning, sales orders, estimate, and the production management itself. A production order is an authorization to make the product, it collects the cost of materials, labor, overhead and other costs, and receipts the finished product into inventory. Materials and labor can be directly issued to production orders and/or backflushed at count points. ==Quick Release== The [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_50_00_00|Release Production Orders] ([~/?ScreenId=AM500000|AM500000]) form provides a means to quickly release all the planned production orders and print the corresponding paperwork. A printed production ticket can be used by plant personnel to prepare and record material and tooling issues; as work instructions for production employees; to record operation labor, completed, and scrap quantities; and to identify the product being produced as work travels through the production process. ==Alternate BOMs and Routing / Revisions== The user can specify right on the production order what BOM / Routing to use. Therefore, if there is another BOM or Routing that can be used for this Inventory item, the user can specify that alternate on the production order. By default, the primary BOM will be used. In addition, if the user wants to specify to produce to a prior revision of the BOM or routing, they may specify that revision number on the '''References''' tab of the [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_20_15_00|Production Order Maintenance] ([~/?ScreenId=AM201500|AM201500]) form. ==Scheduling== Production orders can be scheduling infinitely backwards and forward using the operation cycle times, or if the ''Advanced Planning and Scheduling'' (APS) feature is enabled on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\CS_10_00_00|Enable/Disable Features] ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) form, finite forward and backwards. ==Event History== The system maintains a complete event history of the production order; from how the order was created, to when it was closed and every step in between. The user can then review the '''Event History''' tab to see what actions have taken place against the production order. Posting events create inventory, labor, and/or cost batches which can be drilled down and traced into the general ledger. ==Easy Release of Materials== Materials can be released on multiple ways. The [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_30_00_00|Materials] ([~/?ScreenId=AM300000|AM300000]) form provides you with ability to manually release materials. The [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_30_00_10|Materials Wizard] ([~/?ScreenId=AM300010|AM300010]) form provides you with ability to select multiple production orders and release all the required materials. On the [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_50_30_00|Release AM Documents] ([~/?ScreenId=AM503000|AM503000]) form, you can release balanced production transaction batches. Materials may be backflushed into the production order. Materials may also be issued based on a purchase receipt which can be seen on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_30_55_00|Unreleased Material Allocations] ([~/?ScreenId=AM305500|AM305500]) form. ==Easy Posting of Production Operation Labor and Completions== Employees can easily post their labor and quantities completed or scrap using the [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_30_10_00|Labor] ([~/?ScreenId=AM301000|AM301000]) form. Alternatively, with backflushing enabled for an operation, only count point operations can be reported either by labor or move transactions. If desired, Acumatica ERP integration scenarios can be used to import labor and move transactions.

Allocations in Production In this topic, you will read about item allocation in production management. In the following diagram, you can see the general concept of allocating items. Allocations for production Allocating Purchase Orders to Production Orders Using Critical Materials Process or Checking Mark for PO When you create purchase orders by using processes on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM401000|AM401000]) Critical Materials (AM401000) or the ([~/?ScreenId=PO505000|PO505000]) Create Purchase Orders (PO505000) form, an allocation is created from the PO to the production material line. The purchase order line created will be Goods for MFG for stock items or Non-Stock for MFG for non-stock items. Once the purchase order is created the allocations on the production order materials line are updated. The supply allocation type depends on the status of the purchase order: Purchase for Prod. Prepared: When the purchase order does not have a status of Open . Purchase for Production: When the purchase order is status is Open . Changing the status or changing the hold flag will change the allocation type. The demand for production orders for purchased items is shown as Production to Purchase . When the purchase order is received the demand allocation is updated to Production Allocated for the quantity received. Using APS Scheduling If the Advanced Planned and Scheduling feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form, when you use the ([~/?ScreenId=AM501000|AM501000]) Rough Cut Planning (AM501000) form to process production orders, available purchase orders will be allocated. The allocation type will be the same as above. The line type of the purchase order is not updated when the line is allocated to a production order. Allocating Stock Items to Production Orders You can manually allocate available items or remove an allocation to a production order by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM209000|AM209000]) Production Order Details (AM209000) form. The demand allocation is Production Allocated . Currently, you cannot allocate a specific lot- or serial-tracked item. Allocations are only removed when the actual quantity issued is equal to the quantity required or when the production order is closed. Completing a production order does not relieve the allocations because the material has not been fully issued. If you need to close a production order short (you were going to make 10 but because of a shortage you could only make 8), then reduce the Qty to Produce and then close the order. Allocating Production Orders to Sales Orders If the production order is created from the sales order it creates a SO to Production demand allocation. When the production order is created the supply allocation depends on the status of the production order: Production for SO Prepared: The production order has a status of Planned or has been placed On Hold . Production for SO: The production order is has a status of Released or In Process and is not On Hold . When the production move creates an inventory receipt the SO to Production allocation is decreased and the SO Allocated increased. If the inventory item is lot or serial tracked, the lot or serial number is allocated to the sales order line. Allocating Production Orders to Other Production Orders When you create linked production orders by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM401000|AM401000]) Critical Materials (AM401000) form, the subassemblies are allocated as Production Allocated . The supply allocations are dependent on the status of the created production order: Production for Prod. Prepared: The production order has a status of Planned or has been placed On Hold . Production for Production: The production order is has a status of Released or In Process and is not On Hold . MRP and Allocations The process of regenerating MPR performed on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM505000|AM505000]) Regenerate MRP (AM505000) form has been modified to use the allocation details for planning regardless of availability calculation rules specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201500|IN201500]) Availability Calculation Rules (IN201500) form.

Costing Production Receipts When you receive items from a production order by using the labor or move transactions, an inventory receipt is created on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN301000|IN301000]) Receipts (IN301000) form to debit the inventory account and subaccount and to credit the work in process (WIP) account/subaccount. If the stock item being received has a valuation method of Standard Cost , then the receipt cost is quantity received multiplied by the standard cost for the stock item and warehouse. For FIFO , Average , and Specific valuation methods, the receipt cost is calculated depending on the costing method selected for the production order. You can read more about the costing and valuation methods in Item Costs and Valuation Methods. Costing Methods Production orders support two costing methods and the default method for new production orders is defined on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM102000|AM102000]) Production Preferences (AM102000) form. The Actual method uses only the actual WIP balance to calculate the cost; the Estimated method combines actual and planned costs to cater to situations where material and labor transactions are not always reported before the inventory is receipted from the production order. Actual Costing Method The calculated unit cost for the manufacturing to inventory transactions, such as inventory receipts, will be the WIP balance divided by the quantity completed, including scrap if the option to include scrap is used. There will be no planned cost estimating calculated into the unit cost of the production receipt. When using this method, the WIP Balance is zeroed after each receipt and there will never be a WIP Balance on the production order when the order is completed. This method may be appropriate when: More or less material is used based on testing the process; for example, add salt to taste or add calcium until the Ph value equals to a particular value. A different material is added or substituted based on availability or inspection; for example, a repair order when parts need to be replaced. Labor times are estimated or unknown until the work is performed. Actual Cost Examples Example 1 Production order to produce 10 units currently has an actual WIP Total of $100 with zero completed units (MFG to Inventory is zero). A user creates a move transaction to complete 5 units into inventory. The total cost for the transaction will be $100 with a calculated unit cost of 100 / 5 = $20 each. After the move transaction another $70 is added to the production order making the actual WIP Total $170 and a WIP Balance of $70. A user creates a move transaction for the final 5 units. The move transaction is for a total of $70 with a calculated unit cost of 70 / 5 = $14 each. The order is complete with a WIP Total of $170, WIP Balance of zero, and MFG to Inventory of $170. Receipt cost summary: $20.00 $14.00 Example 2 Production order to produce 10 units currently has an actual WIP Total of $0 with zero completed units (MFG to Inventory is zero). A user creates a move transaction to complete 5 units into inventory. The total cost for the transaction will be $0 with a calculated unit cost of 0 / 5 = $0 each. After the move transaction the first costs are added to the production order totaling $170 making the WIP Total $170 and a WIP Balance of $170. A user creates a move transaction for the final 5 units. The move transaction is for a total of $170 with a calculated unit cost of 170 / 5 = $34 each. The order is complete with a WIP Total of $170, WIP Balance of zero, and MFG to Inventory of $170. Receipt cost summary: $0.00 $34.00 Example 3 Production order to produce 10 units currently has an actual WIP Total of $170 with zero completed units (MFG to Inventory is zero). A user creates a move transaction to complete the full 10 units into inventory. The total cost for the transaction will be $170 with a calculated unit cost of 170 / 10 = $17 each. The order is complete with a WIP Total of $170, WIP Balance of zero, and MFG to Inventory of $170. Receipt Cost Summary $170.00 Accurate costs with the cost method of Actual therefore are dependent on the reporting of all required transactions before inventory is received from production. Costs are also affected if materials are set to backflush and negative inventory balances are not allowed; the materials that are short will NOT be issued. Because the receipt costs are calculated based on the WIP balance at the time of the receipt, this may have an undesired impact on your costs when the units are issued or shipped. Transactions created and processed by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM308000|AM308000]) WIP Adjustment (AM308000) form adjust the WIP balance and will be included in the cost of any receipt posted after the adjustment. Production order variances are still calculated for each cost element in order to provide a means to measure performance. Estimated Costing Method The estimated costing method uses a combination of actual and planned costs. Very often in manufacturing the actual product flows through production processes faster than the transactions to track it are reported. For example, employees might indicate the labor hours and materials used on the production tickets which are then collected at the end of their shift and reviewed by a supervisor who then submits them for data entry. The product may have already been packed, moved into inventory, and shipped before the actual labor and materials have been posted. Without having the actual labor and materials reported the value in WIP is understated and doing a receipt without these costs will result in an understated receipt cost. In order to minimize the impact of understated costs, the labor and move transactions calculate a receipt cost based on the labor and materials actual hours and quantities plus the difference between and planned and actual labor hours and quantities. Additionally, machine, tooling, and overhead costs are also calculated and applied. The can result in a WIP balance that is only resolved when the production order is financially closed even for stock items using FIFO , Average , or Specific Cost valuation methods. If you are using Standard Cost valuation method for your assemblies, then the receipt cost is always the current standard cost and any rate or usage variances are applied as a WIP Variance when the production order is financially closed. Updating Planned Costs If you are aware of significant labor, material, or other costs changes since the production order was created, you can use the Calculate Planned Cost action on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201500|AM201500]) Production Order Maintenance (AM201500) form if the order has a status of Planned or the order is on Hold and has a status of Released or In-Process . Impact of Using Estimated Costs There are a few issues with using the combination of planned and actual costs that you need to be aware of. The planned costs are calculated using the current values at the time the production order is created and costs may change. Actual costs are determined at the time the materials, labor, or move batch is released and processed by the system. For example, the cost layer to use for FIFO valuation materials is determined when the Inventory Issue batch is released, not when it is created. There are other examples of cost differences between planned and actual costs: A purchase receipt may change the average or last cost of a stock item component or the standard cost has been updated. Planned Labor is calculated using work center standard rates and you report labor using employee rates that are different. Rate changes were made work center, overhead, machine and/or tooling after the production order planned costs were calculated. Differences between the planned unit costs and actual unit costs are considered Rate Variances . Differences between planned quantities and actual quantities are Usage Variances . How Does Scrap Affect Cost? Scrap affects the cost calculations for all valuation methods except Standard Cost. If the Include Scrap in Completions check box is selected on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM102000|AM102000]) Production Preferences (AM102000) form, the receipt cost will be divided by the completed units to calculate the unit cost. For example, the production order called for 10 units to be produced, the WIP Balance is $100.00 without any variances, and a receipt of 9 units completed and 1 scrap is entered: With Include Scrap in Completions checked , the unit cost is $11.11 ($100.00 / 9 Units completed), the production order status is set to Completed , and WIP is credited for the $100.00. With Include Scrap in Completions unchecked , the unit is $10.00 because only 9 units were completed, the production order status remains In Process , and WIP is credited for $90.00. There is no separate accounting entry generated by reporting scrap, the only impact is how the receipt cost is calculated. If there are yield variances you can report the difference as a scrap amount if the Include Scrap in Completions check box is selected on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM102000|AM102000]) Production Preferences form. Scrap quantities can be positive (added to quantity completed) or negative (subtracted from quantity completed). For example, if the planned quantity to produce was 500 units but the actual yield was 510 units, you can enter -10 as scrap. If you have already expensed the cost of scrap, then total scrap is ignored since the WIP Balance was already reduced by the scrap expense. See Handling Production Scrap and Waste for more information. Rate Variances vs. Usage Variances Rate variances will not create a production order variance, the full value of WIP is credited at production completion if the actual quantity completed equals the quantity to produce. If you do a partial receipt, you may get a different cost for each receipt depending on when labor and material are posted to the production order. Usage variances, however, can result in a production order variance and WIP balance at completion. Usage variances are created in the following cases: There is a difference between the planned and actual labor hours. There is a difference between planned and actual material issue quantities Any WIP balance for completed production orders is relieved when production orders are (financially) closed which creates a credit or debit to the WIP Variance account. The unit cost of completed items is not changed during the financial close. Receipt Cost Calculations The receipt cost calculation for assemblies having a valuation method other than Standard Cost compares the planned quantities of labor and materials at planned costs to the actual quantities of labor and materials at actual cost. The calculations are performed for each operation and summarized. The cost calculations are not complex but they are very detailed to ensure a representative cost for receipts. They consider not only the actual costs posted but also the costs that should have been posted when an operation or material issue has not been reported. Before calculating the operation costs, the final operation production quantity (including scrap if configured in production preferences) is used if necessary to adjust prior operation completion quantities if they are less. For example, given this routing and operation 0030 is the last operation and you report a quantity completed of 6: Operation Actual Completed Quantity Adjusted Completed Quantity 0010 10 N/A quantity is greater than 0030 0020 4 6: The operation actual completion quantity is made equal to the last operation completed quantity, 0030 6 6 Labor Cost Calculation Labor costs are calculated for each operation by using the following formula, if the actual labor hours are less than planned labor hours. Actual labor amount + (Planned - Actual labor hours) * Work center standard rate Materials Cost Calculation Material costs are calculated for each material item by using the following formula, if the actual quantity issued is less than the planned quantity to issue. actual material cost + (planned quantity - actual quantity) * planned unit cost Machine and Tools Cost Calculations These costs are always backflushed according to the actual quantity completed at each operation or, if necessary, by the adjusted quantity completed. Fixed Overhead Cost Calculation If not already calculated, the fixed overhead is calculated for each operation. Variable Overhead Cost Calculation Similar to labor and materials cost calculations, the variable overhead is calculated according to the actual quantity completed at each operation or, if necessary, by the adjusted quantity completed. Updating Production Orders to Recognize All Costs If labor and/or material usage variances should be included in the production receipt or completion costs and not as a variance, by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM209000|AM209000]) Production Order Details (AM209000) form you can update the production order operations and materials planned hours and quantities to be the actual hours and quantities before performing a receipt.

Data Entry Settings This information is repeated in the form reference topic for the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201100|AM201100]) Production Order Types (AM201100) form. The purpose of these settings is to assist users in reporting the correct quantities for production transactions. These settings affect the behavior of the materials, labor, and move transactions and are intended to reduce the possibility of data entry errors. If you are using data collection devices and software from a third party you need to make sure they will honor the data entry checks. Setting Description Under Issue Material This checks if the quantity being reported on a move or labor transaction has enough material issued to cover the quantity. This includes the current and all previous operations. If the Actual material is less than the planned quantity based on the quantity being moved the condition exists. The options for this setting: Allow: No error message is displayed. Warn: A warning message is displayed only when the batch is saved but the transaction can continue. If the user releases the batch, no message is generated. Not Allow: The transaction cannot be released unless the issue is resolved by issuing more material or decreasing the quantity reported. This box is unavailable when the value in the Function box is Disassemble . Under Issue Backflush Material This checks if the quantity being reported on a move or labor transaction has enough material to backflush to cover the quantity. This includes the current and all previous operations. If the Actual material is less than the planned quantity based on the quantity being moved the condition exists. The options for this setting: Allow: No error message is displayed. Not Allow: The transaction cannot be released unless the issue is resolved by decreasing the quantity reported. This box is unavailable when the value in the Function box is Disassemble . Over Issue Material This checks if the material being issued on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM300000|AM300000]) Materials (AM300000) form exceeds the quantity remaining to be issued. Allow: No error message is displayed. Warn: A warning message is displayed but the transaction can continue. Not Allow: The transaction cannot be released unless the issue is resolved by returning material or decreasing the quantity reported. Additionally the Include Unreleased Batch Qty check box will include the quantity on unreleased Materials batches; unreleased batches have a status of Balanced or On Hold . Checking this option may increase the processing time if there are a large number of unreleased material batches. Issue Material Not On Order This option can warn or prevent the entry of a materials transaction for a component not specified on the production order. The options are: Allow: No error message is displayed. Warn: A warning message is displayed but the transaction can continue. Not Allow: The transaction cannot be released unless the issue is resolved by correcting or removing the inventory item or by adding the inventory item to the order by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM209000|AM209000]) Production Order Details (AM209000) form. Move on Completed Operations This checks if the operation has a status of Completed for a move or labor transaction. The options for this setting are: Allow: No error message is displayed. Warn: A warning message is displayed only when the batch is saved but the transaction can continue. If the user releases the batch, no message is generated. Not Allow: The transaction cannot be released. Over Complete Orders This checks if the production order has a status of Completed for a move or labor transaction. This is particularly important for the final operation of a production order; the final operation generates a receipt into inventory. This in intended to prevent duplicate and over receipts into inventory. The options for this setting are: Allow: No error message is displayed. Warn: A warning message is displayed only when the batch is saved but the transaction can continue. If the user releases the batch, no message is generated. Not Allow: The transaction cannot be released. Default operation move qty If selected, the Qty Remaining for the operation defaults to the quantity for a move transaction. This does not apply to labor transactions.

Sometimes the products you produce need to be issued out of inventory and disassembled to salvage their components. The item may be obsolete, returned non-functional from a customer, have appearance flaws that would not be accepted. or maybe purchased just for the value of a component. The disassembly process allow users to manage and track the disassembly process of a product, capture related costs, and put the usable component parts back into inventory. Defective or non-recoverable components can be scrapped. Disassemble type production orders are used to capture the costs incurred and a single-step disassembly transaction, which can be processed by using the [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_30_15_00|Disassembly] ([~/?ScreenId=AM301500|AM301500]) form, used to record the inventory issue, scrap, and component returns to stock.{br}{TOC} ==Features== The following features are provided:[anchor|#_bdace115-3982-4c3a-add1-00d958453482] *Generates an issue transaction for the item being disassembled and a receipt for the components salvaged. *Allows for scrap of disassembled component materials. *Create a new disassemble production order based on disassemble order type. *Create a disassembly transaction directly on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_30_15_00|Disassembly] ([~/?ScreenId=AM301500|AM301500]) form (and select a disassembly production order) or on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_20_15_00|Production Order Maintenance] ([~/?ScreenId=AM201500|AM201500]) form. *The source for materials to be returned by the disassemble process can be a bill of material or copied from another production order. *Disassembly entry allows for batch correction (reverse previous disassembly entry). *By-products not supported for disassemble orders. *Allows actual labor entry. *Copies predefined attributes from the order type, bill of material, and source production orders to the disassemble orders. *Allow for entry of attribute values for disassembly transactions. *Allows for override of the unit cost of materials returned to stock.
==Processing Disassemble Production Orders== Although production orders are used for disassembly the processing steps have been simplified.[anchor|#_57c9f9f6-dee8-420f-9786-d4bceea69645] *A disassembly transaction is performed in a single step. The item to disassembly is issued from inventory and the salvaged components received into inventory. *The ''Release Materials'' and ''Auto Create Linked Orders'' actions are cannot be used for disassemble production orders. *The disassembly transaction will generate Inventory Issues and Receipt for the ''Disassembly ''transaction and Inventory Adjustments for ''Correction ''transactions. *Disassemble production orders can be selected only on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_30_15_00|Disassembly] ([~/?ScreenId=AM301500|AM301500]) form. ==Configuration Requirements== The disassembly process is the part of production management. Before you can use the process the you must create a production order type with the ''Disassemble'' function on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_20_11_00|Production Order Types] ([~/?ScreenId=AM201100|AM201100]) form.[anchor|#_cb5ae424-fb40-4764-b992-aca5dd9bc15d] *The order type can use a different numbering sequence and GL accounts. *Define the following on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_10_20_00|Production Preferences] ([~/?ScreenId=AM102000|AM102000]) form: **The '''Disassembly Numbering Sequence''' for the disassembly transactions. **The optional '''Default Disassembly Order Type'''.
