Alternatively, remove the unnecessary operations, clear backflush, and/or set their run and machine times to zero. ))) ==Accounting== The costing method for disassemble production order is ''Actual''. Any difference between the value of inventory issued and returned or scrap is booked to WIP Variance account when the production order is closed. When releasing the disassembly transaction the following accounting entries are generated:[anchor|#_e123ffba-cad5-4d56-8f75-c24e3330e8d3] *Credit Inventory and debit Work in Process account for the cost of the item being disassembled. *Debit Inventory and credit Work in Process for the component returned to stock. *Credit Work in Process and debit the scrap expense account for components scrapped. *Credit Work in Process and debit the inventory account for components scrapped. *Debit Work in Process and credit the expense accounts for labor, overhead, tools, and/machines.

Disassembly Process Sometimes the products you produce need to be issued out of inventory and disassembled to salvage their components. The item may be obsolete, returned non-functional from a customer, have appearance flaws that would not be accepted. or maybe purchased just for the value of a component. The disassembly process allow users to manage and track the disassembly process of a product, capture related costs, and put the usable component parts back into inventory. Defective or non-recoverable components can be scrapped. Disassemble type production orders are used to capture the costs incurred and a single-step disassembly transaction, which can be processed by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM301500|AM301500]) Disassembly (AM301500) form, used to record the inventory issue, scrap, and component returns to stock. Features The following features are provided: Generates an issue transaction for the item being disassembled and a receipt for the components salvaged. Allows for scrap of disassembled component materials. Create a new disassemble production order based on disassemble order type. Create a disassembly transaction directly on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM301500|AM301500]) Disassembly (AM301500) form (and select a disassembly production order) or on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201500|AM201500]) Production Order Maintenance (AM201500) form. The source for materials to be returned by the disassemble process can be a bill of material or copied from another production order. Disassembly entry allows for batch correction (reverse previous disassembly entry). By-products not supported for disassemble orders. Allows actual labor entry. Copies predefined attributes from the order type, bill of material, and source production orders to the disassemble orders. Allow for entry of attribute values for disassembly transactions. Allows for override of the unit cost of materials returned to stock. Processing Disassemble Production Orders Although production orders are used for disassembly the processing steps have been simplified. A disassembly transaction is performed in a single step. The item to disassembly is issued from inventory and the salvaged components received into inventory. The Release Materials and Auto Create Linked Orders actions are cannot be used for disassemble production orders. The disassembly transaction will generate Inventory Issues and Receipt for the Disassembly transaction and Inventory Adjustments for Correction transactions. Disassemble production orders can be selected only on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM301500|AM301500]) Disassembly (AM301500) form. (On this form, only disassemble orders can be selected). Move and material transactions are not required and the forms do not allow the selection of disassemble production orders. Configuration entry performed on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM306000|AM306000]) Configuration Entry (AM306000) form cannot be run for disassembly production orders. However, you can disassemble a configured item by using the production order that made it as the source. Labor transactions do allow selection of disassembly order types, but restrict entry to any quantity related fields. Disassembly orders do not require operations. Unlike Move/Labor transactions which are operation specific, the disassembly entry does not provide an entry for operation number for the production item. Disassemble orders use the same production order status codes (for details, see Production Order Statuses) as regular orders. Configuration Requirements The disassembly process is the part of production management. Before you can use the process the you must create a production order type with the Disassemble function on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201100|AM201100]) Production Order Types (AM201100) form. The order type can use a different numbering sequence and GL accounts. Define the following on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM102000|AM102000]) Production Preferences (AM102000) form: The Disassembly Numbering Sequence for the disassembly transactions. The optional Default Disassembly Order Type . You may want to create a separate bill of material for disassembly production orders otherwise you may be adding additional costs for operations marked for backflush. Alternatively, remove the unnecessary operations, clear backflush, and/or set their run and machine times to zero. Accounting The costing method for disassemble production order is Actual . Any difference between the value of inventory issued and returned or scrap is booked to WIP Variance account when the production order is closed. When releasing the disassembly transaction the following accounting entries are generated: Credit Inventory and debit Work in Process account for the cost of the item being disassembled. Debit Inventory and credit Work in Process for the component returned to stock. Credit Work in Process and debit the scrap expense account for components scrapped. Credit Work in Process and debit the inventory account for components scrapped. Debit Work in Process and credit the expense accounts for labor, overhead, tools, and/machines.

How to Create Rework/Repair Orders A rework or repair order can be used to issue an existing item from inventory, do something to it, and return it to stock with the same or different inventory id. There are a number of reasons why this may be necessary: The item is an old revision and needs to be upgraded. A component from a supplier was found to be defective and needs to be replaced. It was returned by a customer or someone else and needs to be inspected and repaired if necessary. It can be converted into a different item that someone wants. You want to disassemble it for it's parts and dispose it. Create a Repair/Rework Bill of Material If you frequently do repair work for your customers you might create a repair bill of material for the stock item. You would list the operations to be performed and if required, any materials always used in the process. By having a special bill of material you can also add notes, attach procedures, or add attributes to the bill that will be copied to the production order based on the production order type settings specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201100|AM201100]) Production Order Types (AM201100) form. Create a Production Order Type On the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201100|AM201100]) Production Order Types (AM201100) form, you create an order type for repair and rework orders to help identify them and to use different settings, such as: Numbering Sequence WIP and WIP Variance Accounts (only if Posting Class is not used) Default Costing Method Copy Notes Settings Data Entry Settings Create the Production Order To start you need to create a production order for the item you plan to receive into inventory. If the item has a bill of material you can decide if you want to use an existing bill, either the default or a special repair bill, to start and then amend it as necessary by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM209000|AM209000]) Production Order Details (AM209000) form. You delete unneeded operations with their materials; change, delete, or add materials; modify overhead and/or tools as required. Be sure to review the backflush check boxes for an operation or material and clear them when necessary. Alternatively, you can remove the BOM ID on the References tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201500|AM201500]) Production Order Maintenance (AM201500) form. If you do this, you will need to create at least one operation in order to report the quantity completed and issue materials. The first material to add is the inventory item to issue to the production order which can be the same as the item being reworked. If known if advance, you can add other materials to the details or simply issue them as needed during the rework process; there is no restriction on materials being issued that are not in the production details. If some materials are recoverable and are known in advance, make the quantity required a negative and a receipt will be created to return the item to inventory when you use the ([~/?ScreenId=AM300010|AM300010]) Materials Wizard (opened from the ([~/?ScreenId=AM300000|AM300000]) Materials (AM300000) form) to create a materials batch. Whether or not you use an existing bill of material or manually enter the production details you will need to add the item being issued from inventory for repair and this can be the same item you will return to stock or dispose. Although you cannot specify an inventory item as a component of itself in a bill of material because it would cause a circular reference in MRP Regeneration or the Cost Roll process, you can do this for a production order. If you are using posting classes defined on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN206000|IN206000]) Posting Classes (IN206000) form to specify default WIP and WIP Variance accounts, you can override these settings on the References tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201500|AM201500]) Production Order Maintenance form. Returning Materials to Stock If there are components that are removed and can be used elsewhere or need to be returned to vendor, you can enter a negative quantity on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM300000|AM300000]) Materials (AM300000) form. The cost of an item returned to stock is dependent on the Default Returns Cost settings for warehouses. If the materials need further processing (inspection, disposal, repair, return to vendor, etc.), you should indicate a warehouse bin location that is not included in the quantity available calculations and excluded from MRP. The cost of materials returned to stock will credit the work in process account specified on the production order and debit the inventory account associated with each inventory item. Returning Materials to Vendors After returning the item to stock, you use the ([~/?ScreenId=PO302000|PO302000]) Purchase Receipts (PO302000) form to create a vendor return. For more information about vendor returns, see Purchase Returns at the Original Cost: General Information and Purchase Returns at the Calculated Cost: General Information. Posting the Completion or Disposal If the repairs were successful, then you can receive the unit to stock by creating a move or labor transaction. If the unit is lot- or serial-tracked you can use the same lot or serial number or the new one, that is, you can add a suffix to indicate it has been repaired. If the repairs were not completely successful, then you can enter the scrap quantity on the Move or Labor transaction to complete the production order. Using this method can leave a balance for the WIP amount on the production order. Alternatively, you could receive the item into a disposal location and use an Inventory Issue with an appropriate reason code to charge the costs to whatever account you desire. Closing the Production Order The final step is to close production orders by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM506000|AM506000]) Close Production Orders (AM506000) form to zero out any WIP balance and to post those costs to the WIP Variance account. You can update the production order to change the WIP Variance account before closing the order.

How Warehouse Locations Are Selected All production management transactions use the same logic to determine the order in which to display, select, and/or validate the warehouse bin locations. These transactions are managed on the following forms: ([~/?ScreenId=AM300010|AM300010]) Materials Wizard, ([~/?ScreenId=AM300000|AM300000]) Materials (AM300000), ([~/?ScreenId=AM301000|AM301000]) Labor (AM301000), ([~/?ScreenId=AM302000|AM302000]) Move (AM302000), and ([~/?ScreenId=AM401000|AM401000]) Critical Materials (AM401000). Receipts In order to select a warehouse location for a receipt created as a result of a labor or move transaction the location must have the following boxes selected on the Location Table tab on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses (IN204000) form: Active Receipts Allowed Assembly Allowed The Transaction Warehouse defaults to the warehouse specified on a production order. The default receipt location is determined in the following order and must adhere to the above validation rules: The location specified on the production order, which was defaulted when the order was created by the following rules. The location specified in the Default Receipt To box of the General Settings tab on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) form. The location specified in the Default Receipt To box of the General Settings tab on ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form when the transaction warehouse is the default warehouse for the stock item. The location specified in the Receiving Location box of the Location Table tab on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses form when the transaction warehouse is the default warehouse for the stock item. In the absence of default locations, the qualifying locations are listed in the selection list ordered by pick priority. You can override the warehouse and location as required on the transaction as long as the location is qualified. For example, use a defective material location when the stock item may not be up to specifications and needs to be inspected. Issues If the warehouse is specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM209000|AM209000]) Production Order Details (AM209000) form without a specific location then it is the transaction warehouse; if not specified, the warehouse specified in the production order is the transaction warehouse. When selecting a warehouse location to issue materials to a production order the location must have the following check boxes selected on the Location Table tab on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses (IN204000) form: Active Sales Allowed Assembly Allowed The default issue location will be determined in the following order and must adhere to the above validation rules: The location specified in the Default Issue From box of the General Settings tab on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) form. The location specified in the Default Issue From box of the General Settings tab on ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form when the transaction warehouse is the default warehouse for the stock item. The location specified in the Shipping Location box of the Location Table tab on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses form when the transaction warehouse is the default warehouse for the stock item. In the absence of default locations or when an additional location is required, the qualifying locations are selected in order of pick priority. Where creating a materials batch by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM300010|AM300010]) Materials Wizard form or as a result of backflushing the above rules are applied automatically. If you are returning materials to stock (negative issue) the issue rules are applied. If the stock item is a by-product then the receipt rules are used. The rules are not applied when a location is specified for the material on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM209000|AM209000]) Production Order Details form; this will be the only location used.

==Hints== The work in process asset account associated with each production order collects all of the manufacturing expenses (materials, labor, overhead, scrap, etc.). The work in process and inventory asset accounts are the only accounts that are posted with project transactions. Expense transactions (labor, overhead, scrap, etc.) do not post to projects. It is strongly recommended to create a work in process account(s) to be only used for production orders in order to facilitate reconciliation with the GL.[anchor|#_bb2cd5e4-29e1-4406-b0c6-0c6dec609d0d] *You should not purchase items you intend to issue to production orders that reference a project and the '''Update Project''' check box on the production order is selected otherwise you would charge the project twice. *For the above reason, purchase orders created on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_40_10_00|Critical Materials] ([~/?ScreenId=AM401000|AM401000]) form do not reference the project from the production order. Projects are updated when the materials are issued to the production order and the '''Update Project''' check box for the production order is selected. *Inventory items can be issued or received to any valid warehouse location; that is, transactions do not require project-specific warehouse locations. *Estimates do not create accounting transactions and therefore do not update projects. *Project references on estimates do not update the corresponding project references on opportunities or sales orders. *If you have both project and non-project production orders it may make sense to create separate order types on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_20_11_00|Production Order Types] ([~/?ScreenId=AM201100|AM201100]) form to ensure the correct settings for account numbers and costing methods. If you do this, you could also clear the default order type on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_10_20_00|Production Preferences] ([~/?ScreenId=AM102000|AM102000]) form to force the users to choose the correct order type.

Labor Reporting Labor is a component of product cost, both when rolling up the planned costs for bills of material and production orders and when recording the actual times or backflushing the standard times. Recording the actual time spent on production operations and comparing them to the planned costs is part of manufacturing performance reporting. Every production order tracks the variances between planned and actual costs and reports are provided in the module. Even if all or some labor is backflushed you could possibly create a custom inquiry or report to compare the actual labor costs to the earned or standard costs. There are two methods to report labor hours and their resultant cost against production orders: Direct entry by employees using their cost rates or work center standard rates. Backflushing labor by reporting quantities completed at an operation. Both methods can be used concurrently. For example, employees will only report labor against milestone operations and the prior secondary operations will be backflushed for labor. Additionally, non-direct labor, labor not attributed to a production order, can be reported to capture their cost in the GL. Integration with employee time activities (for details, see Time Activities) is supported by using the Create Labor Time Activities Create Labor Time Activities (AM503000) form if the Time Reporting on Activity feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. Prerequisites Whether or not you decide in include the labor element in your costs, the following items are required: GL Accounts: These are the offset accounts used when labor costs are posted to the Work in Progress account of the production order or indirect labor is reported. Labor codes on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM206500|AM206500]) Labor Codes (AM206500) form: The labor code determines the GL account for labor cost. Direct labor requires a labor account and indirect requires both a labor account and an overhead account. Work calendar on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS209000|CS209000]) Work Calendar (CS209000) form: All work centers need to have a calendar. Shifts on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM205000|AM205000]) Shifts (AM205000) form: These are required when adding a work center. Shifts can also be used to factor labor rates for premium hours such as overtime or holidays. Work centers on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM207000|AM207000]) Work Centers (AM207000) form: Standard Cost: This is the cost per hour used when calculating planned costs, backflushing labor, and optionally used when employees report labor. Shifts: You must specify a shift and its associated work calendar and labor code. When employees report their time, they must enter the shift and that defaults the labor code. Backflush Labor: This will be the default when you add an operation for the work center in bills of material. Overhead: They are not required but it may be easier to add them to the work center rather than specifying them on the bill of material for each operation. You can use labor overhead rates calculated on the basis of hours and/or labor costs. Employees Employees, which are managed on the ([~/?ScreenId=EP203000|EP203000]) Employees (EP203000) form: Production Employee: If employees will report direct or indirect labor they must be flagged as a production employee Employee Cost: If you wish you use the employee cost rate, you must specify the rate on the ([~/?ScreenId=PM209900|PM209900]) Labor Cost Rates (PM209900) form. Production Preferences Use Labor Rate : either Standard (uses Work Center Standard Cost) or Employee (use Employee Cost Rate not payroll rate). The work center standard rate is always used when labor is backflushed. Default User Employee ID : If the logged on user is a production employee, then their employee number is populated on the Labor transaction form. Operations in Bills of Material The setup and run time elements for each operation are used to calculate the planned labor cost of a bill of material and production order. Both are extended by the work center standard rate per hour. Setup time cannot be reported; it is only posted when the operation is backflushed. Reporting Actual Hours The ([~/?ScreenId=AM301000|AM301000]) Labor (AM301000) form is used to report hours against production operations as well as the quantity completed, and optionally scrap, at an operation of a production order. This same form is used to report indirect labor. Additionally, production employees can clock on and off of production orders by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM315000|AM315000]) Clock Entry (AM315000) form or the Acumatica mobile app. Reporting of scrap is not allowed Clock entries must be approved by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM516000|AM516000]) Approve Clock Entries (AM516000) form to create a labor transaction batch. Accounting for Labor Costs The WIP account for the production order is debited and the labor account for the labor code is credited. When a quantity completed is reported on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM301000|AM301000]) Labor (AM301000) form, any labor overheads are calculated and debit WIP and credit their respective overhead accounts. You should consider the impact of posting to these accounts, as well as the other cost elements recorded by production management transaction, on your GL. Most companies record their actual factory expenses, such as wages and benefits, equipment costs, production supplies, and utilities to the GL. If both the actuals and the production order transactions are reported you may be posting the same costs twice. You should consider setting up the manufacturing accounts as accrual accounts and debit these accounts to zero when you post your actual costs.

Manufacturing Data Collection Production transactions may be entered using hand held devices supporting the Acumatica mobile app similar to transactions for sale orders, purchasing, and inventory. The Data Entry rules specified for the production order types on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201100|AM201100]) Production Order Types (AM201100) form are enforced. Transactions Supported The following transactions are available: Scan materials on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM300030|AM300030]) Scan Materials (AM300030) form Scan moves on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM302010|AM302010]) Scan Move (AM302010) form Scan labor on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM302020|AM302020]) Scan Labor (AM302020) form Setup and Configuration The Manufacturing Data Collection feature is optional and must be enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. You configure the default options for this feature on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM102000|AM102000]) Production Preferences (AM102000) form. The User Settings on each transaction manage settings specific for the current working mode. In addition, production employees can clock on and off production orders using the mobile version of the ([~/?ScreenId=AM315000|AM315000]) Clock Entry (AM102000) form without having the Manufacturing Data Collection feature enabled.

Production Order Process Flow The following is a typical process flow of a production order from time of entry to closing it out in the system. All of these processes are recorded on the Events tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201500|AM201500]) Production Order Maintenance (AM201500) form. Creating Production Orders Production orders can be created in any of the following ways: Manually by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201500|AM201500]) Production Order Maintenance (AM201500) form By clicking Actions Production Orders on the form toolbar of the ([~/?ScreenId=SO301000|SO301000]) Sales Orders (SO301000) form By using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM510000|AM510000]) Create Production Orders (AM510000) form By using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM401000|AM401000]) Critical Materials (AM401000) form to create child production orders linked to a parent production order By using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM400000|AM400000]) MRP Display (AM400000) from to create multiple orders For orders created from MRP or critical materials, the primary bill of material from the Manufacturing tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) is used to create the production details. For manually created or from sales orders, the source of the production details can be a bill of material, an estimate managed on the Estimate Estimate (AM303000) form, or a configuration managed on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM207500|AM207500]) Configuration Maintenance (AM207500) form. When created, the orders have a status of Planned . Orders with status do not allocate inventory and cannot be posted with any transactions. Releasing Production Orders Production orders may have their status changed to Released directly from the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201500|AM201500]) Production Order Maintenance (AM201500) form. You can also release multiple orders by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM500000|AM500000]) Release Production Orders (AM500000) form. When released, production orders are listed on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN402000|IN402000]) Inventory Allocation Details (IN402000) form and the quantity to product is shown in the On Production Supply box and the materials allocations in the In Production Demand box. Printing Production Tickets Production tickets, which you can view in the ([~/?ScreenId=AM625000|AM625000]) Production Ticket (AM625000) report, can be printed directly on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201500|AM201500]) Production Order Maintenance (AM201500) form or multiple tickets printed by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM511000|AM511000]) Print Production Orders (AM511000) form. If either method is used, the method records the event of printing on the Event History tab of the order. Issue Materials Material transactions managed on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM300000|AM300000]) Materials (AM300000) form, are used to issue materials to production orders. They can be created in any of the following ways: Manually By using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM300010|AM300010]) Materials Wizard form By using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM305500|AM305500]) Unreleased Material Allocations (AM305500) form When confirming vendor shipments on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM310000|AM310000]) Vendor Shipments (AM310000) form Created and released automatically as a result of backflushing when reporting operation completes by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM301000|AM301000]) Labor (AM301000) or ([~/?ScreenId=AM302000|AM302000]) Move (AM302000) forms. When released, an inventory issue is created by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN302000|IN302000]) Issues (IN302000) form to update the component on hand balances as well as the production order details, totals, and work in process balance. You should select the Automatically Post on Release check box on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN101000|IN101000]) Inventory Preferences (IN101000) form to ensure the timely updating of on hand and WIP balances. Alternatively, you can setup an automation schedule for releasing inventory documents by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN501000|IN501000]) Release IN Documents (IN501000) form throughout the day. Issuing materials changes the status of a production order to In Process if not already set. Posting to Operations Posting to the production order operations must be done in order to move the order through the production processes. Each company can decide which operations should be reported and which operations can be backflushed when setting up the bills of material. When reporting quantities completed, any prior operations that have not been reported are reported in the same quantity. Posting to operations changes the status of a production order to In Process if not already set. When the last operation is reported, an inventory receipt is created on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN301000|IN301000]) Receipts (IN301000) form to update the on hand balance of the item being produced. There are two methods used to post operations: When you want to post the actual labor hours to a production order, use the ([~/?ScreenId=AM301000|AM301000]) Labor (AM301000) form. You can also optionally post the quantities completed and scrapped at the same time. When you want to report only the quantities completed and scrapped, use the ([~/?ScreenId=AM302000|AM302000]) Move (AM302000) form. Labor hours and costs are backflushed if set on the operation. Regardless of which form is used, both a cost transaction on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM309000|AM309000]) Cost Transactions (AM309000) form is created to record the transaction details and a GL batch on the ([~/?ScreenId=GL301000|GL301000]) Journal Transactions (GL301000) form is created to debit the work in process account and credit the appropriate accrual accounts for labor, tools, machines, and overhead costs. The latter three cost elements are only posted when quantities are reported and the operation is marked for backflush. They are always issued automatically in proportion to the quantity reported. All costs incurred to date are summarized on the production order and production operations Totals tab. Completing Production Orders When reporting the last operation, if the total of quantity completed is equal to or greater than the quantity planned to produce, the production order status is changed to Complete . You can manually change the status to Complete by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201500|AM201500]) Production Order Maintenance (AM201500) form. When a production order is compete only WIP adjustment transactions managed on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM308000|AM308000]) WIP Adjustment (AM308000) form can be posted to the production order. Closing Production Orders The final process is to close a production order by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM506000|AM506000]) Close Production Orders (AM506000) form, which creates the final adjustment to set the work in process balance to zero by creating a cost transaction on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM309000|AM309000]) Cost Transactions (AM309000) form and a GL batch on the ([~/?ScreenId=GL301000|GL301000]) Journal Transactions (GL301000) form. The offset is added to the WIP Variance account.

Production Order Statuses These are the descriptions of the different statuses for the Production Order Status box on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201500|AM201500]) Production Order Maintenance (AM201500) form. Status Description Planned Production orders start in the Planned status. The supply allocation is Production Supply Prepared ; the material requirements are Production Demand Prepared . Transactions cannot be entered against a production order in the Planned status. You can delete a production order in the Planned status; if the order is linked to a sales order, you will be prompted to confirm the deletion. Released Production orders in the Released status allow transactions to be posted. The supply allocation is Production Supply ; the material requirements are Production Demand . A production order can be moved from the Released status back to the Planned status. Productions orders can be released by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201500|AM201500]) Production Order Maintenance (AM201500), ([~/?ScreenId=AM500000|AM500000]) Release Production Orders (AM500000), or the ([~/?ScreenId=AM503000|AM503000]) Release AM Documents (AM503000) form. In Process When the first transaction is posted against the production order, the status of the production order is automatically moved to In Process . An In Process production order cannot be moved back to Release or Planned . However, your can Complete or Cancel an In Process production order. Hold Production orders in Planned , Released , or In Process status can be moved to the Hold status by selecting the Hold check box. When a production order is in the Hold status, no transactions can be issued against it. If the production order should no longer be on hold, clear the Hold check box. The production order will automatically change back to the status that it was at prior to the Hold status. Therefore, if the production order was released and then put on hold, when it is removed from hold, it will return to the Released status. Cancelled Only a production order that is in process can be cancelled. Once cancelled, the production order cannot be changed back to any other status. You cannot issue transactions against a cancelled production order. If the production order has an open Work In Process, a GL batch will automatically be created to adjust the WIP account value. A production order can only be cancelled on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201500|AM201500]) Production Order Maintenance (AM201500) form. If the order is linked to a sales order, you will be prompted to confirm the deletion. Complete Once all the finished good items have been completed, the status of the production order is completed. As labor or move transactions are entered against the production order, there is a check box that indicates that the operation is completed. When the last operation is completed, the production order is completed. The user can still issue transactions against a completed production order. The production order is completed on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM301000|AM301000]) Labor (AM301000), ([~/?ScreenId=AM302000|AM302000]) Move (AM302000), or the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201500|AM201500]) Production Order Maintenance forms. Closed Once a production order is completed, the next step is to close the production order. This is done through ([~/?ScreenId=AM506000|AM506000]) Close Production Orders (AM506000) form. This form lists all the completed production orders. The user can select the production orders that need to be closed and then click the Process button. If there is a WIP variance on the production order, the system will correct the variance through a GL batch.

Production Order from Sales Order This dialog box opens from the ([~/?ScreenId=SO301000|SO301000]) Sales Orders (SO301000) form when you click Actions Production Order on the form toolbar. You use this dialog box to create and view production orders for any number of sales order lines where the replenishment source of the stock item is Manufactured . If an item does not appear in the list and you think it should, check the following: For the sales order type on the ([~/?ScreenId=SO201000|SO201000]) Order Types (SO201000) form, the Allow Production Orders - Approved or Allow Production Orders - Hold check boxes are selected. The status of the sales order must be other than Pending Approval . The Mark for Production check box must be selected in the sales order line. You can select the Make to Order Item check box on the Manufacturing tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form to make the system select the Mark for Production check box on the sales order line by default. The MTO Order check box is selected for the sales order type to make the Mark for Production check box available in the sales order line. Changes to the sales order line quantity or date do not automatically update the production order. Similarly, deleting the sales order line or deleting or cancelling the sales order do not delete existing production orders. You can however, drill down to the existing production order and make changes to it provided it is in a status that allows changes. If you try to delete or cancel a production order linked to a sales order, you will be prompted to confirm the deletion or cancellation. Alternative Method The creation of production orders can be deferred to a later time or assigned to another user by selecting the Mark for Production check box in the line and by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AM510000|AM510000]) Create Production Orders (AM510000) form. The Mark for Production check box is automatically selected when you add to a sales order an item with the Make to Order Item check box on the Manufacturing tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form. This process does not support creating production orders when the numbering sequence specified in the Order Numbering Sequence box of the General Settings tab on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201100|AM201100]) Production Order Types (AM201100) has the Manual Numbering check box selected on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS201010|CS201010]) Numbering Sequences (CS201010) form. Production Orders Dialog Box The dialog box lists all of the manufactured stock items on the sales order. Table Element Description Selected Select this to enable the creation of a new production order. Only allowed if one has not been created already. Checking the box on the column header will select all lines. Inventory ID This is the inventory ID for the stock item to be manufactured. Subitem This column only appears if subitems are enabled. Quantity The quantity to manufacture for this stock item; you can enter a different quantity, UOM The base unit of measure for the stock item. Mark for Production This indicates that a production order should be created or has already been created for the line. This updates the availability calculations according to settings specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201500|IN201500]) Availability Calculation Rules (IN201500) form. Prod Order Type Enter or select the production order type to create. Only Regular order types are allowed. The default order type is specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM102000|AM102000]) Production Preferences (AM102000) form. Production Nbr This is the production order number if it has been created. You can click the link to open the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201500|AM201500]) Production Order Maintenance (AM201500) form and make changes once the order is created. Status This is the current status of the created production order. The initial status is Planned . Qty Completed This is the quantity completed to date for an existing production order. Production UOM This is the unit of measure for the production order Qty Completed. Line Nbr This is the line number of the sales order and can be used for sorting. The dialog box contains the following buttons. Create Creates production orders for the selected items where a production order has not been already created. Cancel Closes the dialog box without saving changes.

Production Transactions Process Flow and Accounting This topic describes how transactions are used to collect and post costs to production orders and how these transactions affect the general ledger. Transaction Types and Processing The following transactions are used to post to production orders: Labor (which are managed on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM301000|AM301000]) Labor (AM301000) form) Posts direct labor to production order operations and creates a Cost Transaction batch. Allows posting of indirect labor to the indirect labor expense account and creates a Cost Transaction batch. If a quantity completed and/or scrap is entered, other costs related to the operation such as overhead, tooling, and/or machines are automatically posted as well in the Cost Transaction batch. If there are materials specified for the operation that are marked as backflush and a quantity completed and/or scrap is entered, then a Materials batch is created and processed. If the quantity completed is for the last operation, an Inventory Receipts batch is created. If the quantity completed is negative then an Inventory Issues batch is created. Move (which are managed on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM302000|AM302000]) Move (AM302000) form) Same as labor but without posting of labor. Material (which are managed on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM300000|AM300000]) Materials (AM300000) form) Post materials issues. Create Inventory Issues batch for components consumed and an Inventory Receipts batch for by-products. If materials are being returned, that is, a negative quantity was entered on the Materials batch or a negative quantity completed was entered on the Labor or Move transaction and there are materials marked as backflush, the Inventory Issues batch lines have a transaction type of Return . Vendor shipment (which are managed on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM310000|AM310000]) Vendor Shipments (AM310000) form) Creates a materials batch. Create Inventory Issues batch for components consumed. Post the cost to the subcontract totals. WIP adjustment (which are managed on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM308000|AM308000]) WIP Adjustment (AM308000) form) Adjusts the WIP balance and creates a Cost Transaction batch. If a production order is cancelled or closed a WIP Adjustment batch and Cost Transaction batch are created also. The cost adjustment batches (managed on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM309000|AM309000]) Cost Transactions (AM309000) form) create a GL batch to update the work in process and the appropriate expense accounts. Processing Steps In order to ensure that all transactions are flow through the system as required, the following actions occur from the Release action of the source batch: All of the related transaction batches are created ( Materials , Cost , Inventory , and GL ) with a status of Hold . A user cannot edit or release the on hold Inventory or GL batches because the source is not IN or GL. All of the related transaction batches are released. The production orders are updated and the source batch is marked as Released . Should you find a production batch with a status of Balanced where the batch has a reference to an Inventory or GL batch, do not attempt to release the inventory or GL batch. Release the production source transaction batch again and it will process and release the related transaction batches if they already exist and create any that are missing. You may need to add the IN Ref Nbr or GL Ref Nbr to the columns in the details area in order to see the reference. Reversing a Transaction All enterable production transactions can be reversed by entering a negative quantity or hours. The easiest way to accomplish this with a minimum of typing is to find the original transaction batch and create a new batch by copying its settings. You change the appropriate transaction line quantities or hours to a negative value. Then you delete any other lines that you do not need to correct. If batch control totals are used, they must be negative also. Then you release the new batch. When the transaction is to reverse/decrease an inventory receipt from a production order, see Reversing Production Receipts. Cost Transactions cannot be directly entered as they are created by other production transactions. Transaction Accounting Each production order contains the following boxes that get posted as well as the individual cost elements: WIP Total : This is the sum of all actual costs and is updated for every transaction. MFG to Inventory : This is the total of the inventory receipts from the production order and is updated by a Labor or Move transaction for the final operation when a quantity complete is entered. WIP Balance : This is the difference between WIP Total less MFG to Inventory Process Resulting Transactions Enter a production order No accounting transactions Release a production order No accounting transactions. Inventory is allocated and is visible on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN402000|IN402000]) Inventory Allocation Details (IN402000) form. Issue materials to a production order WIP Total and actual Material costs are debited. The stock item Inventory account, or Expense Accrual for non-stock items, is credited using the cost from inventory. Inventory is directly issued by a Materials batch or indirectly as a result of backflushing by a Labor or Move batch. Confirm a vendor shipment A Materials batch is created. The subcontract actual totals are updated. Issue labor to production order Labor transaction only post labor hours and their costs. If a quantity complete and/or scrap quantity is reported, then they will act as a move transaction to recognize other costs. WIP Total and actual Labor costs are debited. Direct Labor is credited using either standard cost from a work center or an employee labor rate. Move Transactions Overhead: WIP Total is debited. Overhead is credited based on the cost rates from the overheads. Machine: WIP Total is debited. Machine is credited for the standard cost rates from the machines. Tool: WIP Total is debited. Tool is credited for the unit cost for the Tools. On the last operation finished items are received into Inventory: The Inventory account is debited. WIP Total is credited. Scrap (Reported with a Labor or Move) Scrap Action: Write-Off: WIP Total is credited Scrap Expense is debited Quarantine: Scrap Expense is credited Inventory account is debited Close Production Order The WIP Variance account is debited or credited for any remaining amount in the WIP Balance . WIP Balance is zeroed out. Cancel Production Order The WIP Variance account is debited or credited for any remaining amount in the WIP Balance . WIP Balance is zeroed out. Cost Elements Updated The following table summarizes which cost elements including the various types of overhead are updated by either labor hours or a quantity completed. This also applies when a move or labor transaction updates prior operations; the prior operation is updated only when a quantity complete and/or scrap is entered on either a labor or move. Cost Element Labor Hrs Quantity Complete Quantity Complete and Operation Set to Backflush Setup Y Labor Y Y Machine Y Y Tool Y Y Overhead Costs OH - Fixed Y Y OH - Variable by Labor Cost Y (1) Y OH - Variable by Labor Hours Y (1) Y OH- Variable by Materials Cost (Only when materials have been issued or backflushed for an operation) Y Y OH - Variable by Machine Hours Y Y OH- Variable by Quantity Complete Y Y OH - Variable by Total Quantity Complete Y Y (1) Only when both a quantity completed and hours are reported using the labor transaction.

When a production order receipt is incorrect you can adjust production order and the inventory on hand balance by creating and releasing a negative move transaction on the [https://help-2020r1.acumatica.com/(W(109))/Wiki/ShowWiki|Move] (AM302000)form. This also applies to labor transactions on the [https://help-2020r1.acumatica.com/(W(109))/Wiki/ShowWiki|Labor] (AM301000) form when a quantity completed is reported. The receipt transaction cost have been incorrect for a number reasons:[anchor|#_51c125e1-0348-49b3-aed4-9a19336c4a39] *The quantity may have been wrong. *The lot or serial numbers were incorrect. *The receipt cost was wrong because transactions were not reported. This is particularly important when you are using Actual Costing. {br}{TOC} ==Creating the Move or Labor Batch== You can directly enter the transaction or paste the original batch into the form. In either case the quantity to be reversed is entered as a negative. The following must be observed:[anchor|#_26272f06-4c21-42c0-94be-39802bc6abf0] #You cannot reverse more than you have completed on the last operation. #If you are reversing labor also, you cannot reverse more than the actual hours reported. #You cannot drive the on hand balance of the warehouse location negative if the '''Allow Negative Inventory''' check box is cleared on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\IN_20_10_00|Item Classes] ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) form. #If the inventory item is lot controlled, you must select an existing lot and the quantity cannot exceed the on hand balance. For multiple lots, you must enter each lot on a separate line. #If the inventory item is serialized, you must enter each serial number on a separate line. #If the inventory item has a FIFO valuation method, you must select the receipt number to adjust and the quantity cannot exceed the receipt quantity. If more than one receipt number, each receipt must be on a separate line.
These business rules are validated and enforced by the inventory adjustment on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\IN_30_30_00|Adjustments] ([~/?ScreenId=IN303000|IN303000]) form. ==Transaction Processing Details== If the transaction is valid, then:[anchor|#_44de5f1c-8edd-4fec-991e-fafdb93c5041] *The Inventory Adjustment batch is released and updates the on hand balance and unit cost. *The production order ''Quantity Completed'' and ''Quantity Remaining'' are adjusted *The production order total for ''MFG to Inventory'' is reduced by the extended cost. *The production order total for ''WIP Total'' is increased by the extended cost. *A cost batch is created to credit WIP and debit the labor (when the backflush is checked), overhead, machine, and tool costs. ((({S:Warn}Materials batches created by the initial transaction because of backflushing will not be reversed. )))

Reversing Production Receipts When a production order receipt is incorrect you can adjust production order and the inventory on hand balance by creating and releasing a negative move transaction on the Move Move (AM302000)form. This also applies to labor transactions on the Labor Labor (AM301000) form when a quantity completed is reported. The receipt transaction cost have been incorrect for a number reasons: The quantity may have been wrong. The lot or serial numbers were incorrect. The receipt cost was wrong because transactions were not reported. This is particularly important when you are using Actual Costing. Creating the Move or Labor Batch You can directly enter the transaction or paste the original batch into the form. In either case the quantity to be reversed is entered as a negative. The following must be observed: You cannot reverse more than you have completed on the last operation. If you are reversing labor also, you cannot reverse more than the actual hours reported. You cannot drive the on hand balance of the warehouse location negative if the Allow Negative Inventory check box is cleared on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) Item Classes (IN201000) form. If the inventory item is lot controlled, you must select an existing lot and the quantity cannot exceed the on hand balance. For multiple lots, you must enter each lot on a separate line. If the inventory item is serialized, you must enter each serial number on a separate line. If the inventory item has a FIFO valuation method, you must select the receipt number to adjust and the quantity cannot exceed the receipt quantity. If more than one receipt number, each receipt must be on a separate line. These business rules are validated and enforced by the inventory adjustment on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN303000|IN303000]) Adjustments (IN303000) form. Transaction Processing Details If the transaction is valid, then: The Inventory Adjustment batch is released and updates the on hand balance and unit cost. The production order Quantity Completed and Quantity Remaining are adjusted The production order total for MFG to Inventory is reduced by the extended cost. The production order total for WIP Total is increased by the extended cost. A cost batch is created to credit WIP and debit the labor (when the backflush is checked), overhead, machine, and tool costs. Materials batches created by the initial transaction because of backflushing will not be reversed.

Production Management: Implementation Checklist These the mandatory and optional steps required to successfully configure the Production Management to fit your business needs. You can at any time adjust the settings as your business grows and changes. For example, you may decide not to have employees directly report their labor when first implementing the functionality. No. Task Description 1 Configure the numbering sequence for production batches Use the ([~/?ScreenId=CS201010|CS201010]) Numbering Sequences (CS201010) form to define the numbering sequences for production batches. There are numbering sequences for Move, Labor, Materials, WIP Adjustment, Cost, Disassembly, and Vendor Shipments transaction batches on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM102000|AM102000]) Production Preferences (AM102000) form. The length can be consistent with the length of the numbering sequences used in Inventory Preferences in case you want to use them in reports. You can use the same numbering sequence for all transactions or create sequences for each. The document type identifies the transactions. 2 Define the numbering sequences for production orders Use the ([~/?ScreenId=CS201010|CS201010]) Numbering Sequences form to define the numbering sequences for production order numbers and indicate the sequence in each of the production order types on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201100|AM201100]) Production Order Types (AM201100) form. 3 Determine the default labor rate and labor handling The default rate will come from either the standard rate on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM207000|AM207000]) Work Centers (AM207000) form or the ([~/?ScreenId=EP203000|EP203000]) Employees (EP203000) form. Labor can be handled by standardizing cost from the work center or by recording actual time against an operation. To define production employees, select the Production Employee check box on the ([~/?ScreenId=EP203000|EP203000]) Employees form. Select the needed value in the Use Labor Rate box on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM102000|AM102000]) Production Preferences (AM102000) form. 4 Import the automation definitions On the toolbar of the ([~/?ScreenId=AM102000|AM102000]) Production Preferences form, you click Import Automation Definition . This will open the ([~/?ScreenId=SM205010|SM205010]) Automation Definitions (SM205010) form. Then you click Active Definition . This enables key configuration information for printing production tickets, printing vendor shipment forms, and for creating approval workflows for engineering change control. 5 Define the production order types You must define at least one order type with a function of Regular and at least one type with a function of Planned ; you can only transact against Regular order types. Order types are maintained using ([~/?ScreenId=AM201100|AM201100]) Production Order Types form. The Planned type is used in the MRP part of manufacturing functional area. 6 Determine the default Work in Progress Variance accounts/subaccounts These can be changed on specific production orders. Use the ([~/?ScreenId=GL203000|GL203000]) Subaccounts (GL203000) form. Do not use accounts with an Account Group ; account groups are used in project management if the projects functionality is used in the system. You can use the ([~/?ScreenId=IN206000|IN206000]) Posting Classes (IN206000) form to configure how these accounts are defaulted. If not specified by the posting class setting, they are defaulted from the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201100|AM201100]) Production Order Types form. Do not use the WIP accounts as the inventory account for inventory items or for any other transactions so you can tie the balance in GL to the ([~/?ScreenId=AM654000|AM654000]) Work in Process (AM654000) report. 7 Determine if fixed manufacturing lead time or variable lead times will be used Fixed manufacturing lead time is dependent on the stock item or item warehouse details and is defined in total days to completion. Variable lead time is based on operational setup, run and queue times and their efficiency factors. See Lead Time Concepts for more information on how fixed and variable lead times are used. Specify the Fixed MFG Calendar ID on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM102000|AM102000]) Production Preferences form. 8 Determine handling of production order scrap Use the ([~/?ScreenId=AM102000|AM102000]) Production Preferences form. Scrap can be counted or not counted against the operation quantity completed. The accumulated scrap from all operations determines if a production order can be set to Completed and will affect the cost of the receipt into stock when included. 9 Determine is scrap will be expensed or quarantined. Create ([~/?ScreenId=CS211000|CS211000]) Reason Codes (CS211000) for the scrap expense. If scrap will also be quarantined, create a warehouse and location to store the scrap on hand balances. See Handling Production Scrap and Waste for more information on configuring scrap processing. 10 Determine which sales order types allow production orders to be created If you plan to create production orders directly from sales orders, you must select the Allow Production Orders - Approved or Allow Production Orders - Hold check boxes on the ([~/?ScreenId=SO201000|SO201000]) Order Types (SO201000) form. 11 Define the default costing method for production orders. Costing methods are explained in Costing Production Receipts. The default method is specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201100|AM201100]) Production Order Types form. 12 Select the data entry settings These help to ensure the integrity and accuracy of production transactions. The settings can be configured to Allow , Warn , or Not Allow move or labor transactions to report quantity completions if material has not been issued, is already completed, or over complete. They can be set for each of the defined order types on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201100|AM201100]) Production Order Types form.

There is no closing procedure for production management itself but because of its integration with inventory and general ledger functional areas there are processes that should be completed before closing the integrated modules.{br}{TOC} ==Release Production Transaction Batches== There could be transactions that have been entered but not released. Their status can be ''Balanced'' or ''Hold''.[anchor|#_fc1f4f35-4132-4bfd-838e-2a764e870791] *To process balanced batches **The [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_50_30_00|Release AM Documents] ([~/?ScreenId=AM503000|AM503000]) form lists all of the transaction batches that have a status of ''Balanced''. You can open the batch from this form to review the data and release the batch from the form or just select the batches to process. *To find batches on hold, do the following: **Use the [HelpRoot_ReportReference\AM_62_20_00|Production Batch Register] ([~/?ScreenId=AM622000|AM622000]) report and add the {{AMBatch.Status = On Hold}}filter on the '''Additional Filtering Conditions''' tab. **:((({S:Hint}If you are looking for all unreleased transaction, you can add a second line to the report filter {{Or AMBatchStatus = Balanced}}. ))) **Use the [HelpRoot_ReportReference\AM_00_00_11|Transactions By Production Order] ([~/?ScreenId=AM000011|AM000011]) report to find the all of the unreleased batches.
==Close Production Orders== Closing completed production order zeros out the WIP balance and generates a WIP adjustment transaction on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_30_80_00|WIP Adjustment] ([~/?ScreenId=AM308000|AM308000]) form. The [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_50_60_00|Close Production Orders] ([~/?ScreenId=AM506000|AM506000]) form lists the production orders that have been completed. Any order with a significant WIP Balance should be reviewed to determine if transactions were not posted or there have been data entry errors. A production order cannot be closed if it is in an unreleased transaction batch. Even if a production order has a status of ''Completed'', additional transactions may be entered to correct the actuals.((({S:Warn}Transactions posted to production orders after they have been completed do not update the cost statistics for the item produced. If the received costs must be updated you may be able to reverse the move or labor transaction, post the missing transactions, and do the move labor transactions if the item produced still has a sufficient hand balance. )))

Period Closing Tasks There is no closing procedure for production management itself but because of its integration with inventory and general ledger functional areas there are processes that should be completed before closing the integrated modules. Release Production Transaction Batches There could be transactions that have been entered but not released. Their status can be Balanced or Hold . To process balanced batches The ([~/?ScreenId=AM503000|AM503000]) Release AM Documents (AM503000) form lists all of the transaction batches that have a status of Balanced . You can open the batch from this form to review the data and release the batch from the form or just select the batches to process. To find batches on hold, do the following: Use the ([~/?ScreenId=AM622000|AM622000]) Production Batch Register (AM622000) report and add the AMBatch.Status = On Hold filter on the Additional Filtering Conditions tab. If you are looking for all unreleased transaction, you can add a second line to the report filter Or AMBatchStatus = Balanced . Use the ([~/?ScreenId=AM000011|AM000011]) Transactions By Production Order (AM000011) report to find the all of the unreleased batches. Close Production Orders Closing completed production order zeros out the WIP balance and generates a WIP adjustment transaction on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM308000|AM308000]) WIP Adjustment (AM308000) form. The ([~/?ScreenId=AM506000|AM506000]) Close Production Orders (AM506000) form lists the production orders that have been completed. Any order with a significant WIP Balance should be reviewed to determine if transactions were not posted or there have been data entry errors. A production order cannot be closed if it is in an unreleased transaction batch. Even if a production order has a status of Completed , additional transactions may be entered to correct the actuals. Transactions posted to production orders after they have been completed do not update the cost statistics for the item produced. If the received costs must be updated you may be able to reverse the move or labor transaction, post the missing transactions, and do the move labor transactions if the item produced still has a sufficient hand balance.

row.Content: Production orders that have had transaction posted represent your work in process inventory, The work in process balance is updated by every production transaction with a cost. Each production order can have a different work in process account and subacount or use the same account and subaccounts. ==Before Creating Production Orders== The WIP accounts used in production management should have a zero balance. If they do not, you will not be able reconcile the production work in process balances to your general ledger. ==Reconciling Each Period== Similar to inventory where the [HelpRoot_ReportReference\IN_61_55_00|Inventory Valuation] ([~/?ScreenId=IN615500|IN615500]) report can be used to validate the GL account balances, the [https://help-2020r1.acumatica.com/(W(109))/Wiki/ShowWiki|Work in Process] (AM654000) report should agree with the GL account balances. Use the total of the ''WIP Balance'' column for each account and subaccount.

To Create a Production Order To begin processing a production order for a stock item, you create a production order on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201500|AM201500]) Production Order Maintenance (AM201500) form. To Create a Production Order Open the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201500|AM201500]) Production Order Maintenance (AM201500) form. In the Summary area, the order type is defaulted from the ([~/?ScreenId=AM102000|AM102000]) Production Preferences (AM102000) form. Select the stock inventory item. The warehouse and location are defaulted from the item–warehouse storage defaults. On the General Settings tab, review the following: The Qty to Produce is defaulted from the item–warehouse manufacturing settings for the greater of Lot Size and Min.Order Qty . The default UOM from the stock item base unit. The default Scheduling Method is Start On with the Constraint date set to the current business date. On the References tab, Source : If the stock item is not configurable, the Source is BOM and the BOMID defaults Item Warehouse manufacturing tab settings, and the BOM Rev. is the most recent active revision. If the stock item is configurable, the Source is Configuration and the current Configuration ID ; is defaulted from the Item Warehouse manufacturing tab settings, and the Conf. Rev. is the active revision. On the References tab, in the Financial Settings section, the WIP Account , WIP Subaccount , WIP Variance Account , and WIP Variance Subaccount are defaulted from the stock item Posting Class settings if present, otherwise from the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201100|AM201100]) Production Order Types (AM201100) form. On the form toolbar, click Save .

Then on the form toolbar, you can click '''Inquires''' > '''Production Details''' to open the [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_20_90_00|Production Order Details] ([~/?ScreenId=AM209000|AM209000]) form or directly from the menu. The are restrictions that apply depending on the production order progress to date. Refer to the form reference for the restrictions. ==To Change Production Order Details== #Open the [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_20_90_00|Production Order Details] ([~/?ScreenId=AM209000|AM209000]) form. #To modify or add a new operation, select the operation line or click the '''Add Row''' button on the table toolbar. The new operation number can be inserted before, between existing operations, or at the end by specifying the appropriate operation number. ##Enter or modify the operation details. ##If you delete an operation, the associated details ('''Materials''', '''Steps''', '''Tools''', and '''Overhead''') are deleted also. #To modify or add new materials, overhead, steps, and/or tools, select the operation line and enter the data on the appropriate tabs.[anchor|#_56aedcc6-e3a5-4701-a7ef-a447c6b7c42f] #On the form toolbar, click '''Save'''. #Return to the [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_20_15_00|Production Order Maintenance] ([~/?ScreenId=AM201500|AM201500]) form, clear the '''Hold''' check box and on the form toolbar, click '''Save'''.

To Change Production Order Details To change the production order details, you should first select the Hold check box on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201500|AM201500]) Production Order Maintenance (AM201500) form for a production order you want to change to prevent other users from processing transactions for it. Then on the form toolbar, you can click Inquires Production Details to open the ([~/?ScreenId=AM209000|AM209000]) Production Order Details (AM209000) form or directly from the menu. The are restrictions that apply depending on the production order progress to date. Refer to the form reference for the restrictions. To Change Production Order Details Open the ([~/?ScreenId=AM209000|AM209000]) Production Order Details (AM209000) form. To modify or add a new operation, select the operation line or click the Add Row button on the table toolbar. The new operation number can be inserted before, between existing operations, or at the end by specifying the appropriate operation number. Enter or modify the operation details. If you delete an operation, the associated details ( Materials , Steps , Tools , and Overhead ) are deleted also. To modify or add new materials, overhead, steps, and/or tools, select the operation line and enter the data on the appropriate tabs. On the form toolbar, click Save . Return to the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201500|AM201500]) Production Order Maintenance (AM201500) form, clear the Hold check box and on the form toolbar, click Save .

To issue materials to production orders, you use the [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_30_00_00|Materials] ([~/?ScreenId=AM300000|AM300000]) form. The production order status cannot be ''Planned'', ''Closed'', or ''Cancelled''. ==To Issue Materials to Production Orders== #Open the [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_30_00_00|Materials] ([~/?ScreenId=AM300000|AM300000]) form. #The default '''Date''' and '''Post Period''' are defaulted from the current business date. #Optionally you can enter a '''Description''' for the materials transaction. #Add an new row to the table. #Enter the '''Order Type''' if not defaulted and the '''Production Nbr''', '''Operation ID''', '''Inventory ID''', and '''Warehouse'''. The issue from '''Location''' is defaulted from the item–warehouse storage settings. ##If the inventory item is not on the production details and the order type data entry settings are set to '''Warn''' for '''Issue Material not on Order''' the warning icon is displayed for the '''Inventory ID''' but you can proceed. ##If the inventory item is not on the production details and the order type data entry settings are set to '''Not Allow''' for '''Issue Material not on Order''' the not allowed icon is displayed for the '''Inventory ID''' and you cannot proceed. #The '''Quantity''' column is defaulted to the remaining quantity to be issued when have selected the correct operation. ##If the '''Quantity''' is greater than the quantity remaining and the [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_20_11_00|Production Order Types] ([~/?ScreenId=AM201100|AM201100]) data entry settings are set to '''Warn''' for '''Over Issue Material''', the warning icon is displayed for the '''Quantity''' but you can proceed. ##If the '''Quantity''' is greater than the quantity remaining and the [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_20_11_00|Production Order Types] ([~/?ScreenId=AM201100|AM201100]) data entry settings are set to '''Not Allow''' for '''Over Issue Material''', the not allowed icon is displayed for the '''Quantity''' and you cannot proceed. #You can enter additional rows on the form #If the document is on hold, clear the '''Hold''' box. #If the '''Validate Document Totals on Entry''' check box is selected on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_10_20_00|Production Preferences] ([~/?ScreenId=AM102000|AM102000]) form, enter the '''Control Qty''' and '''Control Amount''' on the top of the form. #On the form toolbar, click '''Release'''.
==Using the Materials Wizard== The [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_30_00_10|Materials Wizard] ([~/?ScreenId=AM300010|AM300010]) form reduces the data entry effort by automatically selecting the materials required for production orders. *You can invoke the process directly from a production order by clicking '''Actions''' > '''Release Materials''' on the toolbar of the [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_20_15_00|Production Order Maintenance] ([~/?ScreenId=AM201500|AM201500]) form. *You can invoke the process by clicking the '''Wizard''' button on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\AM_30_00_00|Materials] ([~/?ScreenId=AM300000|AM300000]) form.

To Issue Materials to Production Orders To issue materials to production orders, you use the ([~/?ScreenId=AM300000|AM300000]) Materials (AM300000) form. The production order status cannot be Planned , Closed , or Cancelled . To Issue Materials to Production Orders Open the ([~/?ScreenId=AM300000|AM300000]) Materials (AM300000) form. The default Date and Post Period are defaulted from the current business date. Optionally you can enter a Description for the materials transaction. Add an new row to the table. Enter the Order Type if not defaulted and the Production Nbr , Operation ID , Inventory ID , and Warehouse . The issue from Location is defaulted from the item–warehouse storage settings. If the inventory item is not on the production details and the order type data entry settings are set to Warn for Issue Material not on Order the warning icon is displayed for the Inventory ID but you can proceed. If the inventory item is not on the production details and the order type data entry settings are set to Not Allow for Issue Material not on Order the not allowed icon is displayed for the Inventory ID and you cannot proceed. The Quantity column is defaulted to the remaining quantity to be issued when have selected the correct operation. If the Quantity is greater than the quantity remaining and the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201100|AM201100]) Production Order Types (AM201100) data entry settings are set to Warn for Over Issue Material , the warning icon is displayed for the Quantity but you can proceed. If the Quantity is greater than the quantity remaining and the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201100|AM201100]) Production Order Types (AM201100) data entry settings are set to Not Allow for Over Issue Material , the not allowed icon is displayed for the Quantity and you cannot proceed. You can enter additional rows on the form If the document is on hold, clear the Hold box. If the Validate Document Totals on Entry check box is selected on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM102000|AM102000]) Production Preferences (AM102000) form, enter the Control Qty and Control Amount on the top of the form. On the form toolbar, click Release . Using the Materials Wizard The ([~/?ScreenId=AM300010|AM300010]) Materials Wizard (AM300000) form reduces the data entry effort by automatically selecting the materials required for production orders. You can invoke the process directly from a production order by clicking Actions Release Materials on the toolbar of the ([~/?ScreenId=AM201500|AM201500]) Production Order Maintenance (AM201500) form. You can invoke the process by clicking the Wizard button on the ([~/?ScreenId=AM300000|AM300000]) Materials (AM300000) form.
